uri:kitsu/anime/synopsis.@value:
A shinigami, as a god of death, can kill any person—provided they see their victim's face and write their victim's name in a notebook called a Death Note. One day, Ryuk, bored by the shinigami lifestyle and interested in seeing how a human would use a Death Note, drops one into the human realm.

High school student and prodigy Light Yagami stumbles upon the Death Note and—since he deplores the state of the world—tests the deadly notebook by writing a criminal's name in it. When the criminal dies immediately following his experiment with the Death Note, Light is greatly surprised and quickly recognizes how devastating the power that has fallen into his hands could be.

With this divine capability, Light decides to extinguish all criminals in order to build a new world where crime does not exist and people worship him as a god. Police, however, quickly discover that a serial killer is targeting criminals and, consequently, try to apprehend the culprit. To do this, the Japanese investigators count on the assistance of the best detective in the world: a young and eccentric man known only by the name of L.

(Source: MAL Rewrite)

uri:kitsu/categories/description.@value: Supernatural might refer to something mythical, mystical, bizarre, or something outside the bounds of accepted reality. There's a shadow of mystery often found in shows involved with this genre. Supernaturally oriented titles are often steeped in folklore, myth, or urban Legend. They may involve strange or inexplicable phenomena, Psychic Powers or emanations, and/or ghosts or other fantastic creatures.

Focuses on unresolved questions, and the efforts of characters to discover the answers to them. Whether curious and deadly events are afoot, or some part of the world itself is strange or inexplicable, or someone's past or identity seems strangely shrouded, these characters are set on learning the truth.

Psychological media delve into mental or emotional states of a character in the midst of a difficult situation, letting you observe them change as tension increases. Internal monologues are a key feature, allowing narration to delve into a character's mind, revealing their innermost ideas and motivations - even as they may be driven to the brink of sanity.

The police (civil servants) are the good guys in the battle against crime. Though they try hard, they are usually outclassed by super-criminals or criminal organizations in anime, requiring the help of special units or some lone hero.

Consistency of the characteristics of persons, plot, objects, places and events seen by the viewer.

A single linear focused plot is highly continuous.

A truly random plot is highly discontinuous.

Anime that fit in the alternative present category usually have technology and society that is very similar to ours, but with differences in both, history and culture, which sometimes are blatantly obvious, but sometimes harder to place; this one can at times be very subjective.

The thriller is a genre of fiction in which tough, resourceful, but essentially ordinary heroes are pitted against villains determined to destroy them, their country, or the stability of the free world. The hero of a typical thriller faces danger alone or in the company of a small band of companions. The protagonist may be a law enforcement agent, a journalist, or a soldier, but typically he or she is cut off from the resources of "their" organization. More often the hero is an ordinary citizen drawn into danger and intrigue by circumstances beyond their control. (Source: Wikipedia)

Asia is Earth's largest and most populous continent, located primarily in the eastern and northern hemispheres and sharing the continental landmass of Eurasia with the continent of Europe. Asia covers an area of 44,579,000 square kilometers, about 30% of Earth's total land area and 8.7% of the Earth's total surface area. The continent, which has long been home to the majority of the human population, was the site of many of the first civilizations. Asia is notable for not only its overall large size and population, but also dense and large settlements as well as vast barely populated regions within the continent of 4.4 billion people.

Source: Wikipedia
Last stronghold for humanity. If Tokyo falls, it's all over. Tokyo Tower will undoubtedly fall anyway.

The Earth is the third planet from the Sun, and the densest and fifth-largest of the eight planets in the Solar System. It is in effect a ball of hot mud, but on the surface it's cold enough, so most of us live on it (or are supposed to). It is circa 4.5 billion years old, and, unless we humans succeed in destroying it over the next couple of centuries, it is expected to last for quite another while, though the changes in the Sun's emissions due to its aging will likely cause the extinction of everything; the species of earthlings are guaranteed to die, even if we fail to kill them -- unless, of course, we find ourselves another planet and figure out a way to take everything there. Our little planet on a corner of this galaxy may mean nothing in the grand scheme of things, but to its inhabitants it is their home, so, as a species, we cherish it dearly, to the point many cultures even to this day deify it. Being the home to the human civilizations, the Earth is the main setting of most fiction, be it anime or otherwise, but not only are many titles set in other places, such as unrelated fantasy worlds, in a considerable number of fictional titles the Earth is actually destroyed by aggressive alien invaders.

uri:kitsu/reviews/content.@value:
An excellent intro to anime, and one that I have and will recommend to anyone interested in anime.  With an original and exciting story that will make
you think and analyze the world it is set in.  This anime can break through the most common stereotypes about your average "Japanese cartoon",
making it accessible to anybody interested in a compelling adventure.  Though it does have some hiccups and I personally dislike the off-beat ending,
the rest of this story has amazing characters and a world that reflects the state of our own society in an interesting way.  A must watch for anyone.

uri:kitsu/reviews/content.@value:
An interesting concept squandered on what devolved into a cat-and-mouse style plot.

My biggest issue with this series was that Light Yagami is one of the least-developed protagonists of any show I've ever seen.  We are given zero
insight into his motivations.  What events in his past caused him to take it upon himself to kill "bad" people?  Why is he so driven?  Why does he
believe in his cause so strongly that he will do anything to survive?  Unfortunately none of these questions are answered, and the picture we are left
with is that Light is a sociopathic killer who uses anyone to get to the top.  His family seem like good and decent people; how'd he become so cold?

There is some cleverness in the first half of the series as we see all the lengths Light goes through to conceal the Death Note while under
surveillance.  L matches Light stride for stride and their interactions are the highlight of this series.  Unfortunately for a series that traffics in
such deeply moral issues, it's lacking a conscience.  There is no one to question Light's power.  No one ever engages in the debate as to whether or
not Kira is good for the world; instead on one side we only see policeman try to hunt him down, and on the other we have Kira cultists who blindly
accept power, and nothing in between.  (Occasionally Matsuda wonders if Kira has made the world a better place, but that line of reasoning goes no
where, and the plot is too cramped with the game of detective work to explore that further.)

We also never directly see the effects of Kira on the outside world and thus have to take Light's word for it that he's built a better world; the
show would have been stronger had we seen how the world had improved (or not) through a regular citizen's eyes (a soldier, a person living in a
formerly crime-ridden neighborhood, world leader, etc.)  Then it would have left it for the audience to decide whether or not Kira's actions were
justified.

The whole series wraps up not in a moralistic ending, but an ending where both parties are motivated simply to "win" the game.  Near doesn't want
to take down Light because he believe Light is evil; he wants him to lose.  Light wants to win, because it seems that all Light really cares about is
winning and advancing his own power.

The Shinigami were another big disappointment.  Rem has more depth than Ryuk.  Ryuk is a bit of a pointless character; he follows Light around and
laughs whenever Light suffers a setback.  Occasionally he offers a little bit of insight or comic relief.  His character could have been developed
much more.

Pros:

--Clever plotting

--An interesting premise

--Some interesting characters (L, Matsuda.)

Cons:

--Zero motivation is given for why Light Yagami decides to kill "bad" people.

--Philosophical and moral ideas take a backseat to contrived battles of wit.

--The long time frame of this anime (six years) muddies the emotional impact of the ending, as hardly any supporting characters from the beginning are
present for the finale.

--Taking down Light is seen as just a "game" and not as any sort of moral commentary.

--Ryuk is a useless character and could have been developed much more.

uri:kitsu/reviews/content.@value:
Death Note is an anime with an incredibly promising concept- a book called the Death Note- if you write the name of someone in it (and if wanted,
conditions and time) while thinking of them, that person is doomed to die- coming into the possession of a human. It explores ideas like vigilante
corruption, morals applied to the law, human lack of self control, and cultish obsession.  
 I was lured into watching this classic by that plot basis and I left extremely disappointed. They could have done so much more with Death Note, but
it ended up falling flat very quickly into it. Its psychological mind games were at first puzzling and intriguing, keeping me on the edge of my seat,
but they soon became incredibly simple and felt almost pointless. The humor in it ruined the serious mood- a little humor is fine, but I feel the
humor should have been left to be portrayed simply through Ls personality instead of forced humorous events. I enjoy comedic anime, but the plot of
this anime is not something I would have put under "comedic".

More and more unnecessary characters were thrown into the vat as the show ran its course, each new character being worse than the last. As the quality
of the cast went down, the plot direction plunged with it, with incredibly questionable decisions made in the plot to the point where I found myself
wondering if the writers just stopped caring about their work and was just writing things to cast at the fans. The serious psychological thriller it
had originally started out as started to morph into another generic try-hard anime. At a certain point I was just watching it so I could say I had
completed it- it was a rather short anime, but it felt like it would never end. Pointless event after pointless event continued to happen simply to
drag out the plot and fill the episode quota. 

Death Note has a lovely overall visual design. Many of the palettes are dark and moody with a contrasting color, the main one being red. A characters
palette often represents parts of their personality/their role in the story. Unfortunately, the animation is rather stiff, but because the art is so
detailed its understandable. I'm not disappointed with this part of the anime at all, and I'm actually somewhat impressed.

I was enjoying it quite a lot at first, but the huge disappointing flop it turned out to be makes my enjoyment rating a 4. It's one of my least
favorite anime I've watched. I'm happy for people who enjoyed it, but unfortunately, I was not one of those people.

Deathnote is masterpiece but i know that there are better anime series out there than this such as GNG, Elfen lied and AoT. Still this is wellmade
anime: story is great and unique, the soundtrack is one of the best anime soundtracks ever, great characters such as Light Yagami and L. But this

in first 26 episodes. Still this is a masterpiece and worthwatching!

uri:kitsu/reviews/content.@value:
Disclaimer: Also posted on Myanimelist   
Fucking Death Note. Because I am not a terrible heartless monster incapable of human emotion, I'm gonna break this review into three sections.
Episodes 1-13, episodes 14-26 and episodes 27-37. This is all my opinion and... okay this is the internet, anything I say against Death Note will
cause instant crusification... I MEAN CRUCIFIXION! Holy shit, I saw the grammar nazi bullet two feet away right there; close one

**Episodes 1-13**

The story here is perfect. The concept alone is clever, creative and very original. I love the setup. The main theme in these episodes is the idea of
morality and the choices we make. It's really mind blowing especially for teenagers in the west who haven't seen many anime before. .All the little
plans L and Light make are simple but also crazy and every time you think "WOAH, I NEVER WOULD HAVE THOUGHT OF THAT." 10/10

The characters are great as well. Light is one of the most morally confused characters ever written. What side he is on or wants to be on is the most
interesting part of these episodes for me and it really changed my view on the world. Everything he does goes along with his ideals, so he never feels
out of character. A landmark in character writing for anime and truly an amazing main character. As for L, I like him even more than Light. For one,
he is so much cooler. L is one of the biggest badasses in all of anime, and that's saying something. I also like how he does things. He breaks the
rules, colors outside the lines and does things the way he wants too. Is there other characters? Nahhhhhh. 9/10

The directing is god-tier. It's so amazing that it can make a game of tennis, eating a potato chip and pencil raping a notebook the coolest thing you
have ever seen. Tetsuro Araki is one of the best directors in the industry, and he can even make shitty shows like Attack on Titan cool, so imagine
what he does with a good show. The character designs themselves are good too. The main problem that the show "looks old" especially for madhouse
standards. 7.5/10

The music is epic latin choruses and it's awesome. There is not much to say. Oh yeah, and the opening is hype as hell. Mamoru Miyano does an amazing
job as Light but Alessandro Juliani does a great job as L in the dub. So Light versus L, dub versus sub. The sound gets a 9/10.

The first 12 episodes of Death Note get a 10/10 and a MUST WATCH score from me. Easily one of the greatest experiences anime has to offer.

**Episodes 14-25**  
Oh my god where do I begin. The story in the second half of Death Note is just plain stupid. Without spoiling anything, it pretty much destroys
everything that made the first twelve episodes great without adding any other positives. Honestly, the story gets an overall 6/10 in this arc Imagine
you are eating a sandwich that you bought at a hot dog stand, and after one bite you realize that it is the greatest sandwich in the entire world. You
share this amazing sandwich with everyone, and it becomes a world famous sandwich, making the hot dog stand owner a millionaire. One day he decides to
stop production on the sandwich and make improvements then release it to the public again. After 3 years when he finally re-releases the sandwich, it
is just a picture of his anus with wonder bread rolled around it. Yeah, I’m just great at analogies aren’t I?

The characters are pretty much funny at this point. Misa is the over the top love interest bland bitch for Light. Light became a simple shonen hero.
Misa’s shinigami might as well be Yuno Gasai with a massive piece of Rei Ayanami shoved up her ass. And Higuchi… well Higuchi is just every villain
ever: retard edition. The only character somewhat untouched is L, who was the best to begin with. Characters are a 4/10 in this arc

The animation and sound is pretty much the same, so still 7.5 for animation but 8 for sound because you get used to the epicness.

The second half of Death Note isn’t nearly as good as the first half, but at least it gave a great ending to the series and was overall a 7.5/10 and a
recommendation to stream it. And in the end, the ending is what truly matters… Wait, what do you mean “second third” instead of second half? Oh shit

**Episodes 26-37**

This isn’t going to be as structured as the other parts, because i’ll tell you right now that story and characters gets a 2 and animation and sound
are lowered by 3 points each. The story is ridiculously boring, to the point that I forced myself to keep watching. All the plans are bad, but also
way more confusing. Not smarter, not more clever, not genius, just confusing. No more brilliant but easy to understand plans that make you think
“WOAH, I NEVER WOULD HAVE THOUGHT OF THAT” Instead you just think “Well that was confusing, and from what I could understand a pretty shitty asspull”

Light becomes a full blown copy-pasted antagonist. Yes, the character I called a landmark in character writing, becomes a copy-pasted antagonist. He
is like Bowser minus the amazing video game. Honestly, he is even worse in this arc than he was in part 2. At least he was still kind of on the fence,
especially NEAR the end. But now he is just totally evil. To be fair, the transition from bored teenager to mass murderer did happen pretty fast in
part 1 now that I think about it. As far as I am concerned, Light is the only character in this arc, everyone else is just a husk of plot.  
Okay, for the approx. 0.0000001 of you that haven’t seen Death Note (It’s the most popular anime on MAL) then you should skip this section because I
am going to talk about the ending. What did I think of the ending? I thought it was beautiful… because the show ended at episode 25. No I am not
joking and saying that I don’t know about the 12 episodes after, I am saying that it DID end at that point

The mangaka duo writing death note wanted it to end at chapter 58, when L died. However, the series kept going because Shueisha forced them to
continue, so they had nothing to go upon and just wrote well… that. Bakuman’s ending is even more proof of this, but I won’t spoil a way better
anime/manga \*nudge nudge, wink wink\* \*coughs\* READ BAKUMAN \*coughs\*

So just consider episodes 26-37 a what-if story. I think that the worse thing you can do is continue a story that already ended, then fuck it up. As
such, episodes 26-37 get a 2/10 and a recommendation to watch it, but only because it is pretty much needed in the current anime fandom.

Overall, Death Note gets a 9 out of 10 if you are watching it as it was intended to be watched, and an 8 if you watch it the way it was released.
Death Note is licensed by Viz Media and is available for streaming on Hulu and Netflix.

Episodes 1-13

The story here is perfect. The concept alone is clever, creative and very original. I love the setup. The main theme in these episodes is the idea of morality and the choices we make. It's really mind blowing especially for teenagers in the west who haven't seen many anime before. .All the little plans L and Light make are simple but also crazy and every time you think "WOAH, I NEVER WOULD HAVE THOUGHT OF THAT." 10/10

The characters are great as well. Light is one of the most morally confused characters ever written. What side he is on or wants to be on is the most interesting part of these episodes for me and it really changed my view on the world. Everything he does goes along with his ideals, so he never feels out of character. A landmark in character writing for anime and truly an amazing main character. As for L, I like him even more than Light. For one, he is so much cooler. L is one of the biggest badasses in all of anime, and that's saying something. I also like how he does things. He breaks the rules, colors outside the lines and does things the way he wants too. Is there other characters? Nahhhhhh. 9/10

The directing is god-tier. It's so amazing that it can make a game of tennis, eating a potato chip and pencil raping a notebook the coolest thing you have ever seen. Tetsuro Araki is one of the best directors in the industry, and he can even make shitty shows like Attack on Titan cool, so imagine what he does with a good show. The character designs themselves are good too. The main problem that the show "looks old" especially for madhouse standards. 7.5/10

The music is epic latin choruses and it's awesome. There is not much to say. Oh yeah, and the opening is hype as hell. Mamoru Miyano does an amazing job as Light but Alessandro Juliani does a great job as L in the dub. So Light versus L, dub versus sub. The sound gets a 9/10.

The first 12 episodes of Death Note get a 10/10 and a MUST WATCH score from me. Easily one of the greatest experiences anime has to offer.

Episodes 14-25
Oh my god where do I begin. The story in the second half of Death Note is just plain stupid. Without spoiling anything, it pretty much destroys everything that made the first twelve episodes great without adding any other positives. Honestly, the story gets an overall 6/10 in this arc Imagine you are eating a sandwich that you bought at a hot dog stand, and after one bite you realize that it is the greatest sandwich in the entire world. You share this amazing sandwich with everyone, and it becomes a world famous sandwich, making the hot dog stand owner a millionaire. One day he decides to stop production on the sandwich and make improvements then release it to the public again. After 3 years when he finally re-releases the sandwich, it is just a picture of his anus with wonder bread rolled around it. Yeah, I’m just great at analogies aren’t I?

The characters are pretty much funny at this point. Misa is the over the top love interest bland bitch for Light. Light became a simple shonen hero. Misa’s shinigami might as well be Yuno Gasai with a massive piece of Rei Ayanami shoved up her ass. And Higuchi… well Higuchi is just every villain ever: retard edition. The only character somewhat untouched is L, who was the best to begin with. Characters are a 4/10 in this arc

The animation and sound is pretty much the same, so still 7.5 for animation but 8 for sound because you get used to the epicness.

The second half of Death Note isn’t nearly as good as the first half, but at least it gave a great ending to the series and was overall a 7.5/10 and a recommendation to stream it. And in the end, the ending is what truly matters… Wait, what do you mean “second third” instead of second half? Oh shit

Episodes 26-37

This isn’t going to be as structured as the other parts, because i’ll tell you right now that story and characters gets a 2 and animation and sound are lowered by 3 points each. The story is ridiculously boring, to the point that I forced myself to keep watching. All the plans are bad, but also way more confusing. Not smarter, not more clever, not genius, just confusing. No more brilliant but easy to understand plans that make you think “WOAH, I NEVER WOULD HAVE THOUGHT OF THAT” Instead you just think “Well that was confusing, and from what I could understand a pretty shitty asspull”

Light becomes a full blown copy-pasted antagonist. Yes, the character I called a landmark in character writing, becomes a copy-pasted antagonist. He is like Bowser minus the amazing video game. Honestly, he is even worse in this arc than he was in part 2. At least he was still kind of on the fence, especially NEAR the end. But now he is just totally evil. To be fair, the transition from bored teenager to mass murderer did happen pretty fast in part 1 now that I think about it. As far as I am concerned, Light is the only character in this arc, everyone else is just a husk of plot.
Okay, for the approx. 0.0000001 of you that haven’t seen Death Note (It’s the most popular anime on MAL) then you should skip this section because I am going to talk about the ending. What did I think of the ending? I thought it was beautiful… because the show ended at episode 25. No I am not joking and saying that I don’t know about the 12 episodes after, I am saying that it DID end at that point

The mangaka duo writing death note wanted it to end at chapter 58, when L died. However, the series kept going because Shueisha forced them to continue, so they had nothing to go upon and just wrote well… that. Bakuman’s ending is even more proof of this, but I won’t spoil a way better anime/manga *nudge nudge, wink wink* *coughs* READ BAKUMAN *coughs*

So just consider episodes 26-37 a what-if story. I think that the worse thing you can do is continue a story that already ended, then fuck it up. As such, episodes 26-37 get a 2/10 and a recommendation to watch it, but only because it is pretty much needed in the current anime fandom.

Overall, Death Note gets a 9 out of 10 if you are watching it as it was intended to be watched, and an 8 if you watch it the way it was released. Death Note is licensed by Viz Media and is available for streaming on Hulu and Netflix.

uri:kitsu/reviews/content.@value:
**Story**

The story of *Death Note *is a straight-forward ten out of ten. It has made waves in the anime community with it’s intelligent and gritty plot. *Death
Note *is very well-thought out, creating an intense, three-person battle of wits between Light, L, and the viewer. I say this because when watching
this anime, you don’t simply *watch *it. You pay close attention to every detail in order to fully understand and enjoy everything that’s going on,
and may be extra attentive just so you can try to predict the characters’ next moves. *Death Note *is no simple matter. It is intense and suspenseful
almost from the get-go. I felt smarter just from watching the super-genius characters scheme and investigate. That does not mean the show is without
it’s flaws, but the good far outweighs the bad.

The one plot problem *Death Note *has consists of the whole second half of the show. In order to avoid spoilers, I’m just going to say that things
really start going uphill (normally people would say downhill, but since going down a hill is a preferable alternative to going up a hill, I switched
the two terms) and I, along with many other fans, became irate. The incident that spurs this downward spiral is a huge game-changer that flips *Death
Note *on it’s head. Looking back, it seems that all of this happened just so that there would be more to work with for the remaining episodes, but it
was still infuriating. However, I will say that I really respect the creators of *Death Note *for their choices. Why? Simply because it was a brave
decision on their part that blatantly defied the fan’s expectations for the show. I both love and hate those brave decisions, because although it is
frustrating, it adds a new unpredictability to the show, upping the entertainment level whether you realize it or not.

Now, here’s a touchy subject. The way *Death Note *ends. I really appreciated the ending. It wraps everything up like a massive, spicy burrito,
leaving a sense of bittersweet closure that I believe every show and movie should have. However, many people were angry about this ending for reasons
I cannot say. To each his/her own, I guess. The point is that *Death Note *is a masterpiece, no matter what anyone says about the ending, because the
rest of the show is just too good to dismiss simply because of an ending.

**Animation**

I really don’t have much to say about the animation. It’s nothing spectacular, but it is fluid and easy on the eyes. The artwork is decent and the
character designs memorable. The opening and ending sequences both have great animation that pumps you up for another episode.

**Sound**

*Death Note*‘s soundtrack is amazing. It fits the dark and detective-like atmosphere of the show perfectly, while being pleasant to listen to on it’s
own. There are two openings and two endings, all of which sport great music. Many were shocked after first seeing *Death Note*‘s second opening, but I
liked the song right away. However, I got tired of hearing the same song after a while and it eventually lost it’s charm. I still haven’t gotten tired
of the other songs yet, and I don’t expect to for a long time.

Subbed or dubbed?: Both the Japanese and English versions of *Death Note *are exceptional. The casts of both are quite talented, and Light’s evil
laugh is the perfect example of the voice actors’ capabilities.

**Characters**

Let’s just start with this: I really, really hate Light, (pun intended). But I still love the characters of *Death Note. *While watching the show, I
found it fascinating that I got to choose who’s side I was on. Light and L are two very different sides to one coin, and they both get equal screen
time. You pretty much get to choose who you’re rooting for depending on your morals, or maybe just depending on which one’s personality you like
better. I sided with L, although I know many who preferred Light. That’s really the beauty of the characters. They’re either hated or loved, but
whichever it is, they are still unique, memorable, and so goddamn brilliant that you can’t help but have great respect for them and the ones who
created them. They are all so entertaining, whether it be because of their quirks, their genius minds, or the fact that you occasionally yell curse
words at them when they’re doing something you don’t particularly support, (don’t be ashamed, I yell at the TV too). As if the characters weren’t good
enough already, there is stellar development, especially when it comes to Light and his descent into madness, in addition to the relationships between
characters. The characters are one of the reasons *Death Note *is so great. I have no qualms about them, none at all.

**Enjoyment**

*Death Note i*s an intellectual and emotional train ride, the type where the train is robbed by the bandits of the Old West, (or maybe robots), only
to later have a murder take place all for the sake of a riveting train-murder mystery. As if trains weren’t already cool enough! That is the type of
train ride this anime is, meaning that it is extremely entertaining.

**Recommendation: **I’m guessing you’ve already seen *Death Note, *but if you haven’t, you should definitely take the time to do so.

**Final Conclusion: 9.6/10**

uri:kitsu/reviews/content.@value: *A review of the anime series, Death Note. Also, for any Youtube videos posted here. **DO NOT** view any of the recommended videos or look at any comments since they all contain massive spoilers.* What happens when a boy in high school with a strong sense of morality becomes bored of his life? Now what happens when this same boy one day sees a notebook fall to the ground outside of the window at school, and later after class goes to pick it up**? The combination of these two factors spawns into not only one of those most interesting ideas in anime, but goes on to spawn one of the most popular anime ever made. Even a majority of non-anime viewers have seen this anime, if not, at least know about it.** Death Note was for a lot of people, their first anime. **However, this review is different from others as this show was viewed from the perspective of someone who has already seen a good amount of anime. So how does this show hold up from the perspective of an experienced anime viewer? Well......** (You're pretty good) Death Note was originally a manga that received an anime adaptation and was directed by Tetsuro Araki, who is also known for directing anime like **Guilty Crown (which was great).** Death Note, as stated earlier, follows the story of a boy in high school who discovers a black notebook known as the death note. The death note contains many rules, not all being spelled out or even mentioned aside from the screens that periodically show up throughout the episodes. The most important rule however, is that once you see someone's face and write their name in the book, they will die. No exceptions. The book also comes with a Shinigami (a god of death) to watch over the human who picks up the notebook, in this case, the Shinigami is Ryuk. **Along with Ryuk, who is also bored with his Shinigami life, Light vows to punish evil with the Death Note and become the god of the new world of justice.** The premise of Death Note is nothing, if not, interesting at the least. Death Note, for the most part, consists of Light doing battle with a detective named L in psychological warfare leading to some very epic scenes. The show is split into three arcs and since it'd be spoiler to mention the name of each arc, I'll leave it at that. **The first arc is by far the best, while the second is by far the worst. However, that does not necessarily mean that the second arc is bad, but it never quite lives up to the epic feeling that the first arc leaves with the viewer.** Plenty of moments I was on the edge of my seat, anticipating what master plan Light would have up his sleeve and what plan L had to counteract it. The second arc completely lacks this, and while **the third arc has its moments, it pales in comparison the first arc.** However, the biggest positive to take from this anime is that it never takes itself too seriously, except for a few episodes towards the end. The large amount of tension that is built due to the seriousness of some of the story elements and the constant amount of death, thanks in large part to the death note, is helped played down by the interesting characters and animation. (what a badass)**** **Light Yagami (or Kira)** The main character and the original founder of the death note, also known by his alias Kira**. His character exists for two reasons. One; to set up all of the story elements and give the other characters a reason to exist.** Since he is the "mass murderer" known as Kira, detectives and police force are the only ones that can stop him when no one else dares to challenge him. While Light only wants to punish criminals who have done terrible things, he will not hesitate to kill anyone who gets in his way. After all, Light primarily spends the majority of his time killing while manipulating others into thinking he is not Kira when under suspicion. Two; he is the primary source of entertainment for the viewers of the show. While he does not carry this burden alone, Light Yagami is the driving force that makes the show's events so interesting. His constant planning for what will happen next keeps the viewer excited for what he has up his sleeve (sometimes literally). However, if there is one major flaw of Light Yagami, it is his character as the show progresses. Light is meant to be a super genius as depicted by his really high grades and his mastery over the manipulation of the Death Note and those around him early on in the show**. He tried to never involve others into his plan unless it was absolutely necessary, since he is not the kind of character to rely on others that were lesser than him, which was usually everyone.** As the show progresses, he becomes more arrogant and his plans become less sophisticated, almost child-like, which leads to a **very disappointing conclusion.** And his need to rely on those around him make him feel like less of a genius and more a manipulator. **While one can attribute his arrogance to the madness caused by the constant use of the notebook, I would personally like to think that he should be too smart to fall into a trap like that.** (still badass)**** **L** The main enemy of Kira and the detective in charge of catching him. While no one knows his true name, everyone just refers to him as L or his fake name, Ryuzaki. **As a super genius detective, one would think that L is some badass detective that steals the show every time he appears on screen. Well this is the case, but not in the way you think.** To say L is weird would be an understatement to all weird people out there. He has a lot of quirks to him to make one occasionally question whether he still sane. The dark circles under his eyes, the weird feetle position he sits in when he is....well doing anything, and not only does he have an obsession with eating sweets, but the way he eats them is almost disturbing. Yet, for some odd reason I can't stop eating sweets the same way he does. However, any questions to his character are put to rest once you realize that he is actually a badass. Being the super genius that he is, he is the only one able combat Kira in his own psychological game, always attempting to stay one step ahead of him. **The battles between Kira and L make for some of the best moments in the anime as the level of intensity ratchets up every time Kira makes a move, only to be outsmarted by L, only then to be out-outsmarted by Kira.** There are some other characters that do not play as large roles, yet are still key characters who play their parts very well like Ryuk, Misa Amane, Chief Yagami (Light's dad), Matsuda. Of course there are some hiccups who "nearly" ruined the show, but they are not really worth mentioning. However, there are two minor (and when I say minor I really mean minor) characters that completely make up for some of the other character's shortcomings. The first character is the Shinigami, **Shido (*Sid-do)*, who has the most hilarious dub voice I have ever heard in the history of anime. Every time he speaks, I could not help but crack up. And lastly, there is Matt, who is the best anime character in the history of anime. End of story.** **(best character ever)** The sound of Death Note is arguably the best part of the show. The first thing to mention is the dubbing work of this show. There is no denying that the japanese subbing is good, but the english dub takes it to a whole other level. **Brad Swaile is one of the most underrated voice actor in the business because he does not get nearly enough love since his performance as Light is one of the best voice works in anime history.** Everything is just so perfect with his voice from the crazy laugh, to his description of his plans, to his anger. It works so well. Not to say the rest of the cast is bad, in fact, L's voice actor also does a phenomenal job. But, there is **one scene near the end of the show where Brad Swaile just really sells it, as mediocre as that part itself was story-wise.** The music in this show is especially good. While there are some **"mello"** themes like L's theme. The best tracks in the show come when Kira is just being a complete, evil badass. Describing them won't do it justice, so here's some tracks that go really well with the show. (This one sounds like its straight out of a final boss) **The animation for Death Note is done by Studio Madhouse, the same company that made Trigun, Black Lagoon, and Highschool of the Dead. Along with these amazing shows, they made some great movies like Millenium Actress and some not-as-great movies like Summer Wars.** Still, their track record is beyond impressive and while they are not the best animation studio quality wise, they still make some phenomenal anime. **Death Note's animation is, for the most part, mediocre, with a few moments where it actually shines.** When the camera zooms off the characters and there is actually animation, there is significantly less detail on the characters and sometimes they just look weird**. However, this one of the very few shows where I'd argue that the animation is easily the least important part of the show.** **To save face for the lack of quality animation, what they did was put an extremely high level of detail on character designs, especially on characters like Light Yagami.** I could not even begin to say how amazingly detailed his character is, along with everyone else. **From his eyes, to his evil grin, to his scowl, everything is detailed almost perfectly.** (is there a more badass word than badass?) I also love the character designs of L who looks pretty emo. I found it ironic that his character looks so emo, since he is anything but with his obsession with sweets and his sometimes joking personality. The Shinigami themselves are also very well designed, especially Ryuk. His design reeks of evil, yet I could not help but crack up at him every now and again when he goes crazy over the "human world apples." **The lighting itself is also fantastic and really "shines" in its colorful depiction of some of the characters. During their psychological battles, L is noted by a blue light and Kira is noted by a red light.** And as these characters get deeper into their battles and delve more into their psyches, their color becomes more prominent, especially Light. **However, you want to know the best part of the animation in Death Note? It's the camera.** Clearly the camera guy has way too much fun with his job because whenever the scenes start becoming "epic," the camera, literally, starts going crazy all over the place. It's great because, it actually works. The camera shaking is not really that disorienting, but it just solidifies the one thing you should take away from this show. And that is to not take anything about this show too seriously. (third best scene in the show) And in the end, the shows willingness to occasionally step back and laugh at itself is the best part. And it was also **"nearly"** its biggest weaknesses. Parts one and two never takes itself too seriously except for some specific scenes (which are some of the best scenes in the show). **Part three however, takes itself a lot more seriously and the disconnect from the audience could not be bigger.**{::}**Part three would have been a lot better (other than its stupid conclusion) if the rest of the show was either more serious, or it still retained most of its funny/light hearted moments from the rest of the show.** Another thing that was somewhat annoying was the show's willingness to explain certain events. Sometimes, **Light feels like describing his master plan in an inner monologue in a shonenesque style. Sometimes, he does not.** And it was usually his more complicated plans that he would not describe, while he described the plans we already knew. **Honestly this anime should have just have explained the plans we did not understand, or just explain every plan. I know it feels stupid to ask to be explained something, but remember. This is a gateway anime and is seen by a lot of very new and relatively young anime viewers.** This is only a minor complaint though, since for the most part, I always understood what was going on. **Honestly, there is no better way to describe this show other than the perfect gateway anime because while Code Geass and Fullmetal Alchemist are amazing gateway shows too, they are more of a fantasy/mech setting compared to the more realistic atmosphere of Death Note.** At times it did not even feel like I was watching an anime, with the lack of animation and the very detailed character designs. **If there was ever a show to get anyone into anime, this is it. However, this show is not "nearly" as enjoyable for an experienced anime viewer since a lot of stuff here feels like I have seen it before. Not to say this show was not entertaining.** There was never a time where I felt bored while watching it, even though part 2 did slog a bit at times. **Also that one "scene" between Light and L that made all the fangirls wet in the panties? LOVE it. Religious symbolism at its finest.** **This show is published by Bandai, who unfortunately, went out of business. However you can get this 37 episode anime for the really low price of about $45 (with tax) on Amazon** **(part 1) [http://www.amazon.com/Death-Note-Box-Set-1/dp/B001CZJP0S/ref=sr\_1\_3?ie=UTF8&qid=1387982405&sr=8-3&keywords=death+note][1]** **(part 2) [http://www.amazon.com/Death-Note-Set-2-Various/dp/B00DNQM7M2/ref=pd\_bxgy\_mov\_img\_y][2]** **And I highly recommend this show to anyone, especially for those of you who really want to get your friends into anime. Death Note is not "nearly" the best anime ever made, but it is one damn enjoyable ride, even during its "mello" moments.** Thanks to youtubers eatpotatochip and Gaydolf Schmitler for your youtube videos! A review of the anime series, Death Note. Also, for any Youtube videos posted here. DO NOT view any of the recommended videos or look at any comments since they all contain massive spoilers.

What happens when a boy in high school with a strong sense of morality becomes bored of his life? Now what happens when this same boy one day sees a notebook fall to the ground outside of the window at school, and later after class goes to pick it up? The combination of these two factors spawns into not only one of those most interesting ideas in anime, but goes on to spawn one of the most popular anime ever made. Even a majority of non-anime viewers have seen this anime, if not, at least know about it.

Death Note was for a lot of people, their first anime. However, this review is different from others as this show was viewed from the perspective of someone who has already seen a good amount of anime. So how does this show hold up from the perspective of an experienced anime viewer? Well......

(You're pretty good)

Death Note was originally a manga that received an anime adaptation and was directed by Tetsuro Araki, who is also known for directing anime like Guilty Crown (which was great). Death Note, as stated earlier, follows the story of a boy in high school who discovers a black notebook known as the death note. The death note contains many rules, not all being spelled out or even mentioned aside from the screens that periodically show up throughout the episodes. The most important rule however, is that once you see someone's face and write their name in the book, they will die. No exceptions.

The book also comes with a Shinigami (a god of death) to watch over the human who picks up the notebook, in this case, the Shinigami is Ryuk. Along with Ryuk, who is also bored with his Shinigami life, Light vows to punish evil with the Death Note and become the god of the new world of justice.

The premise of Death Note is nothing, if not, interesting at the least. Death Note, for the most part, consists of Light doing battle with a detective named L in psychological warfare leading to some very epic scenes. The show is split into three arcs and since it'd be spoiler to mention the name of each arc, I'll leave it at that. The first arc is by far the best, while the second is by far the worst. However, that does not necessarily mean that the second arc is bad, but it never quite lives up to the epic feeling that the first arc leaves with the viewer. Plenty of moments I was on the edge of my seat, anticipating what master plan Light would have up his sleeve and what plan L had to counteract it. The second arc completely lacks this, and while the third arc has its moments, it pales in comparison the first arc. However, the biggest positive to take from this anime is that it never takes itself too seriously, except for a few episodes towards the end. The large amount of tension that is built due to the seriousness of some of the story elements and the constant amount of death, thanks in large part to the death note, is helped played down by the interesting characters and animation.

(what a badass)

Light Yagami (or Kira)

The main character and the original founder of the death note, also known by his alias Kira. His character exists for two reasons. One; to set up all of the story elements and give the other characters a reason to exist. Since he is the "mass murderer" known as Kira, detectives and police force are the only ones that can stop him when no one else dares to challenge him. While Light only wants to punish criminals who have done terrible things, he will not hesitate to kill anyone who gets in his way. After all, Light primarily spends the majority of his time killing while manipulating others into thinking he is not Kira when under suspicion.

Two; he is the primary source of entertainment for the viewers of the show. While he does not carry this burden alone, Light Yagami is the driving force that makes the show's events so interesting. His constant planning for what will happen next keeps the viewer excited for what he has up his sleeve (sometimes literally).

However, if there is one major flaw of Light Yagami, it is his character as the show progresses. Light is meant to be a super genius as depicted by his really high grades and his mastery over the manipulation of the Death Note and those around him early on in the show. He tried to never involve others into his plan unless it was absolutely necessary, since he is not the kind of character to rely on others that were lesser than him, which was usually everyone. As the show progresses, he becomes more arrogant and his plans become less sophisticated, almost child-like, which leads to a very disappointing conclusion. And his need to rely on those around him make him feel like less of a genius and more a manipulator. While one can attribute his arrogance to the madness caused by the constant use of the notebook, I would personally like to think that he should be too smart to fall into a trap like that.

(still badass)

L

The main enemy of Kira and the detective in charge of catching him. While no one knows his true name, everyone just refers to him as L or his fake name, Ryuzaki. As a super genius detective, one would think that L is some badass detective that steals the show every time he appears on screen. Well this is the case, but not in the way you think.

To say L is weird would be an understatement to all weird people out there. He has a lot of quirks to him to make one occasionally question whether he still sane. The dark circles under his eyes, the weird feetle position he sits in when he is....well doing anything, and not only does he have an obsession with eating sweets, but the way he eats them is almost disturbing. Yet, for some odd reason I can't stop eating sweets the same way he does.

However, any questions to his character are put to rest once you realize that he is actually a badass. Being the super genius that he is, he is the only one able combat Kira in his own psychological game, always attempting to stay one step ahead of him. The battles between Kira and L make for some of the best moments in the anime as the level of intensity ratchets up every time Kira makes a move, only to be outsmarted by L, only then to be out-outsmarted by Kira.

There are some other characters that do not play as large roles, yet are still key characters who play their parts very well like Ryuk, Misa Amane, Chief Yagami (Light's dad), Matsuda. Of course there are some hiccups who "nearly" ruined the show, but they are not really worth mentioning.

However, there are two minor (and when I say minor I really mean minor) characters that completely make up for some of the other character's shortcomings. The first character is the Shinigami, Shido (Sid-do), who has the most hilarious dub voice I have ever heard in the history of anime. Every time he speaks, I could not help but crack up. And lastly, there is Matt, who is the best anime character in the history of anime. End of story.

(best character ever)

The sound of Death Note is arguably the best part of the show. The first thing to mention is the dubbing work of this show. There is no denying that the japanese subbing is good, but the english dub takes it to a whole other level. Brad Swaile is one of the most underrated voice actor in the business because he does not get nearly enough love since his performance as Light is one of the best voice works in anime history. Everything is just so perfect with his voice from the crazy laugh, to his description of his plans, to his anger. It works so well. Not to say the rest of the cast is bad, in fact, L's voice actor also does a phenomenal job. But, there is one scene near the end of the show where Brad Swaile just really sells it, as mediocre as that part itself was story-wise.

The music in this show is especially good. While there are some "mello" themes like L's theme. The best tracks in the show come when Kira is just being a complete, evil badass. Describing them won't do it justice, so here's some tracks that go really well with the show.

(This one sounds like its straight out of a final boss)

The animation for Death Note is done by Studio Madhouse, the same company that made Trigun, Black Lagoon, and Highschool of the Dead. Along with these amazing shows, they made some great movies like Millenium Actress and some not-as-great movies like Summer Wars. Still, their track record is beyond impressive and while they are not the best animation studio quality wise, they still make some phenomenal anime.

Death Note's animation is, for the most part, mediocre, with a few moments where it actually shines. When the camera zooms off the characters and there is actually animation, there is significantly less detail on the characters and sometimes they just look weird. However, this one of the very few shows where I'd argue that the animation is easily the least important part of the show.

To save face for the lack of quality animation, what they did was put an extremely high level of detail on character designs, especially on characters like Light Yagami. I could not even begin to say how amazingly detailed his character is, along with everyone else. From his eyes, to his evil grin, to his scowl, everything is detailed almost perfectly.

(is there a more badass word than badass?)

I also love the character designs of L who looks pretty emo. I found it ironic that his character looks so emo, since he is anything but with his obsession with sweets and his sometimes joking personality. The Shinigami themselves are also very well designed, especially Ryuk. His design reeks of evil, yet I could not help but crack up at him every now and again when he goes crazy over the "human world apples."

The lighting itself is also fantastic and really "shines" in its colorful depiction of some of the characters. During their psychological battles, L is noted by a blue light and Kira is noted by a red light. And as these characters get deeper into their battles and delve more into their psyches, their color becomes more prominent, especially Light.

However, you want to know the best part of the animation in Death Note? It's the camera. Clearly the camera guy has way too much fun with his job because whenever the scenes start becoming "epic," the camera, literally, starts going crazy all over the place. It's great because, it actually works. The camera shaking is not really that disorienting, but it just solidifies the one thing you should take away from this show. And that is to not take anything about this show too seriously.

(third best scene in the show)

And in the end, the shows willingness to occasionally step back and laugh at itself is the best part. And it was also "nearly" its biggest weaknesses. Parts one and two never takes itself too seriously except for some specific scenes (which are some of the best scenes in the show). Part three however, takes itself a lot more seriously and the disconnect from the audience could not be bigger.Part three would have been a lot better (other than its stupid conclusion) if the rest of the show was either more serious, or it still retained most of its funny/light hearted moments from the rest of the show.

Another thing that was somewhat annoying was the show's willingness to explain certain events. Sometimes, Light feels like describing his master plan in an inner monologue in a shonenesque style. Sometimes, he does not. And it was usually his more complicated plans that he would not describe, while he described the plans we already knew. Honestly this anime should have just have explained the plans we did not understand, or just explain every plan. I know it feels stupid to ask to be explained something, but remember. This is a gateway anime and is seen by a lot of very new and relatively young anime viewers. This is only a minor complaint though, since for the most part, I always understood what was going on.

Honestly, there is no better way to describe this show other than the perfect gateway anime because while Code Geass and Fullmetal Alchemist are amazing gateway shows too, they are more of a fantasy/mech setting compared to the more realistic atmosphere of Death Note. At times it did not even feel like I was watching an anime, with the lack of animation and the very detailed character designs. If there was ever a show to get anyone into anime, this is it. However, this show is not "nearly" as enjoyable for an experienced anime viewer since a lot of stuff here feels like I have seen it before. Not to say this show was not entertaining. There was never a time where I felt bored while watching it, even though part 2 did slog a bit at times.

Also that one "scene" between Light and L that made all the fangirls wet in the panties? LOVE it. Religious symbolism at its finest.

This show is published by Bandai, who unfortunately, went out of business. However you can get this 37 episode anime for the really low price of about $45 (with tax) on Amazon

(part 1) http://www.amazon.com/Death-Note-Box-Set-1/dp/B001CZJP0S/ref=sr_1_3?ie=UTF8&qid=1387982405&sr=8-3&keywords=death+note

(part 2) http://www.amazon.com/Death-Note-Set-2-Various/dp/B00DNQM7M2/ref=pd_bxgy_mov_img_y

And I highly recommend this show to anyone, especially for those of you who really want to get your friends into anime. Death Note is not "nearly" the best anime ever made, but it is one damn enjoyable ride, even during its "mello" moments.

Thanks to youtubers eatpotatochip and Gaydolf Schmitler for your youtube videos!

I had a lot of hope for this anime. When you get into anime you hear about many series (FMA, Steins;Gate, Gurren Lagann, etc.) One of those
recommendations usually follows "OMG, Death note! Mind games and L is so Kawaii" You've probably seen something like that before. Basically this
anime is one that is highly praised and it should be....for the first half. I'll get to that though.  

Warning: Minor spoilers  
 Firstly, the Sound. I'll get to the point, it's amazing. The openings and ending fit the show to a T and the original music that was composed is
very fitting. Don't just take my word though, listen to the pieces such as "Light's theme",   "L's theme", or "Near's theme" These are all
really well done pieces that have a slow rock kind of feel. I don't know why but some of the songs reminded me of the Smashing Pumpkins. 

I didn't watch the sub so I don't know how that is but the dub was done well. Let's be honest though, the dub is worth it just for JYB's portrayal
of Light. He does a spectacular job. I can remember many moments where I was just in awe of his performance or got goosebumps from some of the lines.
The laugh that Bosch does is also well done. After hearing it I can recall many a day where I would practice my own psychotic laugh. Overall, the
soundtrack is very memorable and the dub is enjoyable.

Next, is Animation. Now, i'm not going to pretend like I know anything about animation but from what I saw the animation looks really good. I was
never put off by the animation at all. It seemed to be pretty fluid and at times breathtaking, particularly whenever Light wrote in the Death note. I
do recall some really odd faces but rather than take away from the show I thought it added to it. It helped to illustrate the character's state of
mind to see them making very strange facial expressions. Overall, minus the strange expressions(which some could be put off by.) I found the animation
to be appealing.

Next, we come to Characters. The main characters are interesting. The morals and logic of Light and L is very interesting. The show looks at the
actions of these characters and it felt like at times the show was asking indirectly what my morals were. The show amazed me in that aspect. It
presented various characters with different motives and ideologies. I'm used to the approach that no matter what murder is always bad, so to see the
protagonist arguing that criminals deserved to die was shocking to say the least.

The character of L was interesting as well. He provided the intense logical moments of the show and at times the comic relief. The minor characters
are pretty forgettable. They don't really do or add much until the second half. They're just there to fill up space it seems(looking at you
Matsuda.)

Enter second half, we meet two new characters who become the "antagonists" They didn't appeal to me. They each have their own quirks to make them
stand out because without those quirks they would be flat and uninteresting. They at times annoyed me to the point where I was tempted to fast forward
through their scenes(I didn't though.) Overall, the characters are enjoyable for the most part.

Finally, we come down to Story. This is where my opinion may upset people. The  story was great until the second half. The show changes drastically
from that point. The show also introduces some new characters. One of which is an absolute annoyance. As soon as the character appears, the show
changes gears. This character NEARly solves the mystery from the moment he appears on screen. He puts the pieces together out of nowhere. How? Because
the writers want him to. 

There's no cleverness anymore, if the plot wants X character to learn something then they learn it(whether it makes sense or not.) This could be a
major drawback for some. The worst of it comes in the form of the ending. It was sloppy. It wasn't something that made you go "Oh, I see how that
happened. Makes sense." it was something that made you exclaim "This is the ending?" It didn't feel natural. The entire show(if the supernatural
elements existed) felt like it could happen. The character's way of thinking and the conclusions they came to felt like real people. The ending takes
that away. It doesn't feel natural. It feels like a show. The only reason it happened was because the writers wanted it to. It didn't feel like the
characters came to conclusions on their own but with the help of a script. 

Overall, the show is addicting and downright fun at times until it hits the halfway point then grinds to a halt. In the words of a great anime
reviewer, "The ending is paramount." This ending did not feel paramount. It didn't feel great or important but hastily added to get the show over
and done with. I recommend that you watch it when you have nothing else to do. I don't believe it's worth stopping everything and going out of your
way to watch.

uri:kitsu/reviews/content.@value:
This show went strong for such a long time. I was addicted, and it was perfectly executed. Until, of course, we are introduced to Neer and Mello.
After that, it was all downhill. As much as they attempted to replace L, the nutty genius that we all grew to love, they could never live up to the
standard that had been set by him. But even through this, I had hope in the finale... Which were promptly crushed. There was not a worse way to choose
to end this anime. I would be perfectly alright with Light dying, but the way it was executed was very poor. However, the way they kept you on the
edge of your seat with almost no action whatsoever is a true feat. Despite its obvious flaws, I still adore this anime.

uri:kitsu/reviews/content.@value:
Death Note is one of the best animes in existence and very worth watching. It takes all intelligence to edge of the door and it sometimes opens it to
sneak a glance.

A 17 year old genius boy called Light Yagami finds a notebook called Death Note and uses it to kill criminals and then the best detective in the world
L tries to catch him.

And here is where the story gets very interesting when they play Tom & Jerry but no one knows who's who and they are tying to kill each other and
this leads to a war of brains. I must say I really respect the intelligence this show has, made of a way that will keep you in the edge of your sit
and usually makes you fall of cliff while the greatness of the show scream directly to you. The sound of the anime is really amazing that will become
the drug of your ears from A to Z.

I enjoyed this anime so much that I watched it again and again and the adrenaline never runs out of this show. If you haven't watch it yet what are
you waiting for go right now and watch it or else you will miss one of the interesting animes to date.

That's all I have to say

\- When a human dies, they can never come back to life... EVER.

uri:kitsu/reviews/content.@value:
Death Note. Another famous anime. But this time there is one reason for it. In fact, there are lots of good reasons but they can be summed up in one
thing: this anime is amazing. Want to know why? Then just keep on reading.Story (8): The first half of this anime is a masterpiece. The concept itself
- the Shinigami's notebook which grants the person who has it the power to kill anyone by simply writing the person's name while picturing the face
in his mind - is already brilliant to begin with as it presents the viewer questions like "What would I do if I had that power?" The way it is
developed brings us yet more questions and defies our morals.Light Yagami, the main character, is a brilliant high school student who's angry at all
the injustice in the world. One day, he finds the notebook and he tries it out. At first, he's not sure about if what he did is correct but he ends
up loving the power he got and trying to use it to build a new and better world. He's nicknamed as Kira by the citizens. Of course that would simply
be boring if it wasn't for L, a detective that tries to discover Kira's identity. Both of them are simply genius and their counter clock run to find
out each other's identity is full of intelligent moves and suspense which kept me trying to guess what each one of them would do next.Really, the
simple ingredient that's so great about this story is that it manages to keep you thinking. But at several levels. Let me explain that to you.First,
it makes you think about if what Light's doing is right or wrong. "Is it right to be the judge and executer simultaneously?" "Don't the
circumstances of each crime matter as well and is it right to judge without knowing all the facts?" "Can't the criminals be reformed?" "Is a
world where people don't commit crimes because they're simply afraid really desirable? Isn't what Light aims to achieve theoretically similar to a
dictatorship?" Those are questions that ran through my mind. At one point, I was totally rooting for him. But as the story develops and his actions
begin to change, you'll start to wonder...Second, it makes you think about what's going to happen next. Trying to follow Light's and L's line of
though is both challenging and entertaining. Their move will surprise you and you'll keep trying to guess what they're gonna do next. This show will
keep you on the edge of your sit through its entirety.Third, it changes the way you see the world and the people in it. With each kill and each action
Light takes you can't help but wonder: "It may be wrong but what would I do if I were in his place?". People change, situations make us change. One
different thing in your life and you could be going from a dedicated doctor to a serial killer (just an example).The only problem with the story is
really the second half, for Near isn't nearly as intelligent as L, and Light seems to become way dumber and make pointless decisions rather than
retaining control of the situation. The fact that the resolution didn't steam from Light's mistakes but from someone else's and was pure luck on
Near's part in that regard was both a nice factor (I was rooting for Light to win because... no idea, I just was.) and a rather underwhelming one as
well, for neither of them was the central piece that ended the puzzle. The story receives a 8/10.Art (9): The art is clean, the character designs are
both unique and somewhat similar to reality. The backgrounds are detailed enough and the animation is really good. Even though there are few action
scenes throughout the show, the car chasing scenes for example are really well done. A little exaggerated, yes, but nevertheless pretty good.But were
the art really shines is in the coloring schemes. The dark and dull tones totally fit the anime. And Light's monologues, with the red hair also add a
nice touch.Quite good for its time and genre.Sound (9): First, let's talk about the openings and endings. Well, I dislike both openings and love both
endings. Quite wired isn't it? Because you know, the 1st opening and the 1st ending are both by the band "Nightmare" (they're a really good band
by the way) and the 2nd ones are both by "Maximum the Hormone". Still, it's just my personal preference though some people may be turned of by the
heavy metal sound of the last opening and respective ending. The ending song from episode 37 is really beautiful and fits the last scenes awesomely
well.But that's not all. The opera-like songs that pass in the episodes really add to the scenes and were, with they're somewhat religious tune, the
best choice to set the mood.I can't say much about the voice acting. I watched the english dubbed version and I thought it was good enough but I'm
no expert on that matter.Characters (8): The characters are rather well portrayed. Let me put it this way. When I see an anime, there's always a
character that stands out the most for me, that has characteristics that make me root for him/her. When that doesn't happen, I usually don't enjoy
an anime. In Death Note, no character stood out. But somehow, I still loved it. I think no one stood out because they were all equally great. There
was no one with fantasy-like characteristics. They all seemed like real people with real problems. No unneeded and exaggerated tragedies but no
totally sweet lives either.The character development is pretty much nonexistent for most of the cast, but it doesn't need to be there, for it is
really good for Light Yagami, the main character. Starting of as a genius, calm and collected high school student with a strong sense of morals and
justice, he undergoes a slow but drastic change of character. The more he uses the Death Note, the more he slowly drops his morals because he finds it
is needed to continue his work. He ends up an arrogant person with no consideration by the people who surround him. He starts trying to create a new
and better world for people to live him but ends up obsessed with power and with being the "God of the New World".I love it when Light loses his
memories about the Death Note. He turns back to his old self, refuses to use people as tools (what he had been doing all the time) and he even thinks
Kira is wrong and wants to catch him. At that point, I also thought Kira's actions were going way too far but so did Light. And Light WAS Kira. So
what if the notebook was real, what if I had pick it up? Wouldn't I do the same and end up like that?Moving on to L. He may seem like a plain
character, but he is not. He tried his best to capture Kira risking himself a bit more in each attempt. He seems cold but deep inside I think he
really didn't want Light to be Kira because he had never met anyone so similar to him in his ways of thinking and he saw Light as a friend, even
though he was almost sure that Light was, in fact, Kira.The support characters are surprisingly interesting, despite not being all that well
developed. I'm talking about the task force. At first, we didn't know much about them and they're development is not much noticeable but then at
some point you realize you already know how they feel about Kira, what their line of thought is. The truth is, we subtly get introduced to their
problems and internal struggles. This anime has an interesting cast of supporting characters.My least favorite character was Near. Even Mello was
better developed than him. Near wanted to catch Light, sure. But it seemed like he was barely concerned about anything else that was happening as long
as he could catch him. He was too cold and underwent none changes. Enjoyment (9): This review is getting way too long... Anyway, I really enjoyed this
anime. Each episode got me craving for more. It made me think, it made me feel bad for some characters, it made me hate some situations... It was
truly a great viewing experience. I enjoyed it a lot. Biggest problem was really the second half not being as intelligently scripted as the first one.
But even now, one month after watching, I still think about Death Note and its moral changing story whenever I see some hostage situation on the news.
Sometimes I'm just like "Damn, I wish I had one notebook like that! I could prevent so many bad stuff from happening...". And then, on those
nights, as I'm in my bed the same questions I had when I was watching the show come once again to my mind. "If the notebook was real, wouldn't it
bring even more bad things that it could prevent? Would it be right to use it? What would guarantee that I would not get corrupted by its power?" I
loved this show and I still do.Overall (8): I may rate it a 8, but once again, that's largely due to the second half of the show. Nonetheless, I
recommend this to anyone. Whatever genre of anime you like, you should watch this. It is a really intelligent story and even though you may not love
it as much as I did, the chances are, you will. Even for people who never enjoyed anime, I would still recommend it. In fact, I am now in the process
of making Portuguese subtitles so I can get my mom to watch it. Death Note defies your morals and enables deep discussions with yourself and others.
It truly is a great show.

uri:kitsu/reviews/content.@value:
Story:One of the best things I love about this anime is that it lets you pick who the real hero is. Kira (Light) is a person who thinks that death is
the ultimate solution for crime. L is a person who thinks that criminals should be tried then imprisoned, and just thinks of Kira as a lowly murder.
The perspective of the story is told from Light's view, but you will get to see from L's perspective from time to time. About little over half way
through something happens and the plot takes a turn for the worst until the last two episodes. The last two episodes were simply, epic. Now that word
is over used a lot nowadays but, I am confident that you will think so too.Art:Greatest art style I have ever seen, amazing detail. Awesome character
models.Sound:Not only are the last two openings awe worthy if you like metal, but the music in the anime perfectly sets the mood
perfectly.Character:All characters are designed well and each have their own unique personality. Misa is the happy-go-lucky girl with a feeble mind,
but makes up for it by being Kira's girlfriend and greatest worshiper.Enjoyment:As I said before the story is the absolute best until blank Dies. It
just gets boring for this portion of the anime, but the ending makes up for it all. And my favorite character is introduced during this
period.Overall:Regardless of the dry period, this is my favorite anime ever. It will be very hard for an anime to get better than this in my opinion.
