uri:kitsu/reviews/content.@value: People of the Inter-web, welcome to DivideByZer0's review of the supernatural psychological-thriller: Death Note. Death Note is a 37-episode anime that came out in 2006. It was directed by Director Tetsuro Araki in coordination with the animation studio, Madhouse. Originally, Death Note was a manga series written by Tsugumi Ohba and drawn by Takeshi Obata. Since its release, Death Note's popularity has grown not only throughout Japan but also throughout the western countries, like the Unites States and Canada (through popular networks such as Cartoon Network and Neon Alley). What has made Death Note so popular, you may ask? Well, I'm getting to that part, starting with its plot. Plot: The story is definitely intriguing, mainly because of the battle of wits between Light and L. Almost every episode had an ending that made you want to see more. The plans that L and Light make are definitely not cliché. If anything, the plans that they make to counter each other are very clever and mind-boggling indeed. Some of the plans even made me go "Holy cow! He got you there!". The only problem that I had with the show, plot-wise, was the second half of the series, where almost all the "Holy cow! He got you there!"-moments became non-existent, effectively leading the show to a dwindling road that almost sends it to hell, if not for the climatic ending. The story, and the way that it is set up, also makes you think about the ideologies and principles that the characters are motivated by, whether it may be Light or L's or some other character, and that is always a wonderful touch. Sound: The soundtrack for "Death Note" consists of various orchestral pieces, with choir parts sprinkled into it, effectively adding to the epic nature that the show possesses. Although some of these pieces are used over and over again throughout the series, its execution makes up for it ten times over. Combining the soundtrack with the amazing visuals of the show makes the climatic moments of the show all the more memorable. All the opening and ending themes convey the series' supernatural and psychological theme and are...unique in their own way (I'm looking at you, "What's Up People") and are really fun to listen to on their own. Both the English and Japanese dubs were amazingly done as well, with the voice actors for both Light and L (for both dubs) portraying the characters in such a way that you just either love them or hate them more (in a good way, of course). Characters: There are many reasons to love Death Note's characters. From Light to L to everyone in the Kira investigation team all served a purpose in the show and are not just there because the director needed someone to fill up space. Both Light and L are really unique characters in their own special way, with L being the strange, socially-alien, but quirky, genius, and Light as the perfect model student with delusions of grandeur. Speaking of Light's transition into his delusions, there are also other characters who received a good amount of character development, which makes them all the more interesting. > Seriously, these two are one of the best cat-and-mouse teams out there, almost on par with Tom and Jerry **Animation:** Madhouse is, definitely, an animation company that goes the extra mile when it comes to animating their works. With a mixture of unique color palettes and superb camera angling, Death Note has made even taking a potato chip and eating it really epic. The aforementioned color palettes also deliver a stunning effect that raises the level of suspense and keeps the viewers excited for what’s going to happen next. Enjoyment: Death Note was my first take into the psychological thriller genre and will definitely remain as one of my most favorite anime ever. The story really entranced me with its suspenseful climaxes. Every turn, every plan, and every moment was enjoyable. Even the second half of the show was entertaining, albeit containing less suspenseful moments than the first half. In essence, Death Note is an original, suspenseful, mind-boggling, and tantalizing take into the psychological thriller genre. With the precious combination of its gorgeous soundtrack, enthralling storyline, captivating animation, and unique characters, Death Note is definitely a must-watch! And if you aren’t interested in it by now by my review, may I have please have your full name? I hereby award Death Note with an overall score of 8 Shinigamis out of 10

Originally, Death Note was a manga series written by Tsugumi Ohba and drawn by Takeshi Obata. Since its release, Death Note's popularity has grown not only throughout Japan but also throughout the western countries, like the Unites States and Canada (through popular networks such as Cartoon Network and Neon Alley). What has made Death Note so popular, you may ask? Well, I'm getting to that part, starting with its plot.

Plot: The story is definitely intriguing, mainly because of the battle of wits between Light and L. Almost every episode had an ending that made you want to see more. The plans that L and Light make are definitely not cliché. If anything, the plans that they make to counter each other are very clever and mind-boggling indeed. He got you there!"-moments became non-existent, effectively leading the show to a dwindling road that almost sends it to hell, if not for the climatic ending. The story, and the way that it is set up, also makes you think about the ideologies and principles that the characters are motivated by, whether it may be Light or L's or some other character, and that is always a wonderful touch.

Although some of these pieces are used over and over again throughout the series, its execution makes up for it ten times over. Combining the soundtrack with the amazing visuals of the show makes the climatic moments of the show all the more memorable. Characters: There are many reasons to love Death Note's characters. Both Light and L are really unique characters in their own special way, with L being the strange, socially-alien, but quirky, genius, and Light as the perfect model student with delusions of grandeur. Speaking of Light's transition into his delusions, there are also other characters who received a good amount of character development, which makes them all the more interesting.

Seriously, these two are one of the best cat-and-mouse teams out there, almost on par with Tom and Jerry

Animation: Madhouse is, definitely, an animation company that goes the extra mile when it comes to animating their works. With a mixture of unique color palettes and superb camera angling, Death Note has made even taking a potato chip and eating it really epic. The aforementioned color palettes also deliver a stunning effect that raises the level of suspense and keeps the viewers excited for what’s going to happen next.

The story really entranced me with its suspenseful climaxes. Every turn, every plan, and every moment was enjoyable. Even the second half of the show was entertaining, albeit containing less suspenseful moments than the first half.

In essence, Death Note is an original, suspenseful, mind-boggling, and tantalizing take into the psychological thriller genre. With the precious combination of its gorgeous soundtrack, enthralling storyline, captivating animation, and unique characters, Death Note is definitely a must-watch! And if you aren’t interested in it by now by my review, may I have please have your full name?

If you are looking anime with great character deveploment or psychological thriller then i recommend Death Note for you.

I think the draw of Death Note for me in particular (although this obviously wont resonate with everybody looking into watching it) is that I love
mystery and detective things almost, which is one of the reasons I've just picked up Dangan Ronpa. It's really interesting and clever seeing where
the anime will go next and who'll come out on top; Light or the police force. The series pulls a lot of surprise twists and turns and ultimately I'd
say it's worth the watch just for those alone. It gets a bit dull during a particular segment where a group of businessmen get their hands on the
Death Note, but it's a key part of the story. Nevertheless, it's definitely worth watching.

uri:kitsu/reviews/content.@value:
The anime that tells a story of 2 brilliant minds clashing in an epic duel! This is the first "anime" I have ever watched, but that will not cloud
my judgment, but I have to say, this s not the best anime to start from...

The premise is pretty original as far as anime go, bored shiningami drops death note, bored human picks it up and tries it. After that the police
start going after him, the shiningami decides to follow him around out of boredom until he gets his death note back, and once the police realize he is
no ordinary criminal they send in L, and that is when the story really kicks in!

The story is pretty much flawless, though it\`s mostly Light finding new and creative ways of using the death note, with L always being one step
closer to finding out who this killer called kira really is! It will leave you with your mouth opened, cause there are maybe 2 actions scenes in this
anime, but the mind battles are way better than any action scene you will ever see n any anime. The story is almost flawless with no plot holes or
lame moments happening the first 25 episodes, but right after that it drop\`s from flawless to just great.

The animation is beautiful, and I would expect no less from Madhouse, it makes even the most unimportant scenes look amazing, and trust me, this anime
takes it self so seriously it makes eating chips and writing text into something epic!

The sound is just phenomenal, it\`s so good, that there comes a point where it becomes too good, yup, I never thought I\`d say I, but this anime has
too many good OST. It\`s just one amazing orchestra after another, it just never stops being amazing!

I enjoyed this anime, I truly did, otherwise I would not be here on an anime site reviewing it, since it was my first anime. But I would have enjoyed
it so much more if it knew when and where to end!

Overall it\`s a great anime, should not be missed, this is one of the most universally popular anime, and it\`s one for a reason ;)

is very unexpected and I have no words to say about it.... this is a very intense anime.

uri:kitsu/reviews/content.@value:
Overall, Death Note (1-26) is without a doubt a masterpiece!

It pretty much should have just concluded there. Unfortunately, they had to introduce L's B-Team, Near and Mello, which fucks this idea up, making
the 10 episodes left not even worth considering. Why did it even need to be there? Till this day, I will never know as I still feel it was already
made perfectly. 

I am not going to quote the last 10 episodes of how I feel since it felt like filler BS (honestly). Also, for the last 10 episodes, the character
development was bad compared to the first 26 episodes which sucks big time!

The ending to me wasn't very moving or good and lacked any decisive conclusion compared with the manga. Another thing is that the shinagami Ryuk's
motives are so dumb and lackluster which gives a pathetic look to death gods as a whole.

Not to mention a lack of emphasis on the shinagami world, which I felt could have been touched upon a lot more for a supernatural, psychological
thriller, but even that was lacking as well with a lot of uninteresting tedious scenarios.

Now don't get me wrong, I love this anime almost like if this was my own disrespectful son here, but I will CLEARLY say that this anime isn't a 10
at all! Not by any means. 

However, episodes 1-26 as a whole was. Characters are amazing, the setting is great along with the premise and to me, for a Shonen Jump anime, this is
very unique.

All and all, this show totally deserves its popularity but for an overall high score on MAL, well I guess that can be questionable considering what I
mentioned since I don't rate the last 10 episodes at all.

To this point, I think a lot of people already know where the anime should have ended which leaves me rewarding Death Note with an 8.25 out of 10. 

P.S Don't use your death note on me! I already have a son who's plotting to kill me, damn it!!

uri:kitsu/reviews/content.@value:
“This world is Rotten. Rotten people should be killed off to cleanse this world.” – Light Yagami

Ever wondered what’s it’s like to possess the power to eliminate any person you want in the world, with just a pen and a notebook? Those that cause
pain and suffering to the world find themselves to be in a very vulnerable position in this dark and twisted show. This review may contain spoilers so
please beware!

Story

The story of Death Note centres around high school student Light Yagami. He perceives the world to be corrupt and unfixable in its current state, with
crime and murder ruining the place where we live. He wants these factors to be eradicated from the world, in order to make it a better place for
humans to live. But how can an innocent 17 year old boy possibly do this? With the help of a trusty Death Note of course. Very early into the first
episode, Light comes across this menacing notebook, and is perplexed as to what it is. He takes it home with him only to find out that it has the
power to kill anyone he wishes, with just the simple task of writing their name in the notebook. Light vows to use this notebook to serve justice upon
the crime of the world by deconstructing, and reconstructing his own world where he is the ruler. The story for the most part is very intriguing and
is successful in creating an ominous atmosphere for the audience to encounter. It’s not as simple as research and write every name that has a history
of crime in the notebook. Light engages in several challenging problems across his experience with the notebook. For one he must deal with the force
of the police, and investigator L who attempts to uncover who the person committing all these murders is. This is an effective way of progressing the
narrative because it allows the watcher to experience Light’s intelligence, and how he will use this as an advantage to outsmart the opposing side. He
may even have to compromise because a plan that he had been preparing for a lengthy amount of time was breached by a very small problem, but in fact
will affect many key things later on if the plan was kept as the original. This means that Light has to be a very quick thinker if he does not want
his ultimate secret to be revealed and therefore his downfall. There are numerous unpredictable turns of events throughout the 37 episode span of the
series, that will leave the audience to ponder their thoughts as to what came about Light to attempt something so risky yet sinister. The writing of
the story has been used in an effective way of portraying Light as a very heinous character. Though it’s general to hate such things, having Light as
this paragon of evil sets the tone very well for what the show is trying to be. For the most part, the story was very consistent in quality throughout
the show. Though many argue and say that past around episode 26, the quality dips down a bit, it’s not a significant amount to make the overall
quality of the plot and narrative bad. Many aspects of Death Note’s writing is taken through cognitive manners also. The anime kindly presents several
of Light’s intentions through inner thoughts and monologues to create a sense of foreshadow and an intense vibe to the show. You will surely be amazed
as you watch episode by episode how Light chooses to approach certain obstacles with treacherous yet genius decisions which can allow you to question
his moral standing in society as he continues to serve ‘justice’ to those who oppose him. Story – 8/10

Characters  
Moving on to the characters, I will be speaking of the two most significant in my opinion, Light and L. I will also be giving a brief overview of the
side characters and their significance. 

Light

Light is a 17 year old high school student with a thirst for vengeance. He is usually quite isolated and always thinks to himself, though this is able
to play a big role in his characterisation once paired with the Death Note. He is very deceptive, and will even go to the extent of sacrificing his
own family in order to cover his case regarding the sudden murders, if one were to find out. Having the main character as a debatable antagonist
allows the audience to understand Light’s ideals and what makes him commit the actions that he does throughout the show. His sense of morality is not
one to take lightly, and one can argue that this notebook being bestowed upon him was the source of this slow deprivation of his once known innocence
as he turns into this savage monster with no consideration of others but himself; exerted with pride if you will. Light does develop quite a
significant amount throughout the show, as his own ideals soon come back to oppose against him. These contradicting ideas of Light’s characterisation
allow the audience to judge whether or not they are rooting for Light, or going against his so called ‘justice’. Whichever way you perceive him, he is
a very diverse and detailed character and fits the role he plays well. If I were to criticise his actions slightly, I would say that he sometimes
polarises his first intentions. For example, he states that he wants to protect humanity from the horrors of crime and murder, yet his sometimes kills
innocent civilians throughout the show, just to protect his case from being uncovered. Though this is not too aggravating for some, it could be taken
into account as a flaw. 

L

L's dishevelled and languid appearance is a clear shroud of his great powers of deduction and insight. He tends to second-guess everything he is
presented with, and is very meticulous and analytical with what he does. He is the direct antithesis of Light, with the sole purpose in the anime
being to stop the crimes ‘Kira’ (Light) has committed. I couldn’t say that L possesses higher intelligence than Light, but rather they are balanced in
intellect, but both perform actions that outsmart the other on numerous occasions. He sets himself to be quite at ease with most situations, but also
well aware of the context and matters that must be addressed. His communications with Light are both humorous and though-provoking. Both are trying to
outsmart the other whilst attempting to befriend one another, as L possesses suspicions of Light being the culprit, which the audience knows he is but
Light is able to prevent L from uncovering his secret in many ways. This creates dramatic irony as the audience is able to possess more knowledge of
Light than L himself has. The relationship between each other possesses numerous psychological traits, as they both have different opinions on the
other, than what is really stated in speech between them. The writing allows L to be an extremely likable character, and his contrasting ideals
against Light allowed the audience to choose who they will side with. L is both captivating, but menacing as you are unaware of his future actions to
deal with the crimes he must solve.

Side Characters

Death Note possesses many side characters that contribute to the main plot of the story. These range from Misa, a so-called second ‘Kira’ that adds an
additional element of mystery to the plot, to Light’s father Soichiro who is the leader of the investigation team under L’s command and has yet to
realise that he is opposing his own son. There are also numerous appearances of supernatural 'death gods' throughout the show, who only appear to
those that possess a Death Note. These gods aid in foreshadowing the effects and consequences of using a Death Note, and this helps to create a sense
of danger and pre-eminence that over-ride the story. Though characters like these are not shown as much as Light and L, they still are very
fundamental to add depth and variety to both the plot and characters we see over the course of the show. Characters – 9/10

Art & Animation

The art to Death Note can be described as being ‘morally grey’. The dark overtones that are blended into both the background and the foreground give
justice to the tone of the show. This is because it adds to the atmosphere that Death Note creates with its plot and characters, and allows the
audience to further appreciate the situations due to the colour pallet chosen. Character designs can said to be generic, however aid in the
characterisation of said character. The animation of the show isn’t really something special; however it doesn’t need to be. The animation could be
plain dark and shady, and it would work because of the atmosphere the show puts itself in. Psychological thrillers tend to have a similar colour
choice to each other, as they all attempt to present the same kind of atmosphere and genre. Art & Animation – 8/10 

Soundtrack

The soundtrack to Death Note works immensely well with what it sets itself up to be, in a similar fashion to the art style. The opening and endings to
the show cannot be misinterpreted at all, since they present the themes well. I particularly think that the change in song choice between opening 1
and 2 presents the change in Light’s character throughout the show, as his psychological traits begin to change. The OST’s also used throughout
certain scenes are very well done, as they add to the intense and engaging moments that occur as the show progresses. The sound to the show overall is
done very well, and I don’t think it could’ve been done better. Soundtrack – 9/10

Personal Enjoyment

It would be a lie to say that I did not enjoy this show a lot. The tense moments between Light and L aid in engaging the reader fully, and their
actions throughout the show are able to leave you amazed after you witnessed them. Though it’s evident that the later half of the show was the weaker
segment, this would most definitely not take away from the enjoyment factor that you would get from the show overall. I have also seen both the sub
and dub and would fully recommend either as I feel they are both very good; it's whatever you prefer with watching anime. – Personal Enjoyment – 9/10

Overall

Death Note is a very enjoyable show with many memorable moments that will stick with you for future time to come. It has become one of the most
popular shows in the recent years and will most likely be remembered for years to come. You engage in a very compelling story with many morals that
you are able to take away with you. The soundtrack holds the show justice with its intense musical compositions and the art/animation presents the
morally grey tone that the story sets for itself. Though the weaker second half of the show, I still enjoyed this show very much and would fully
recommend it to anyone who has yet to watch it. I am giving Death Note a 9/10. 

Story – 8/10  
Characters – 9/10  
Animation/Art-style – 8/10  
Soundtrack – 9/10  
Personal Enjoyment – 9/10  
Overall – 9/10

uri:kitsu/reviews/content.@value: > A high-schooler finds a bizarre notebook that can kill anybody whose name is written in it. Who the fuck hasn’t seen this yet? No, seriously. There’s nothing new I can add to this that hasn’t already been said. This is my one and only recommendation to non-anime fans. It’s impossible to talk about without spoiling it. The premise is extremely interesting. It’s very suspenseful. It’s one of those shows where you just have to pop in another episode to see what happens next. The characters are great, especially the main one. It feels clever, and it’s satisfying to see characters trying to out think one another. The reason I’m bringing this up is because Death Note is 7 years old. uri:kitsu/reviews/contentFormatted.@value:
A high-schooler finds a bizarre notebook that can kill anybody whose name is written in it.

Who the fuck hasn’t seen this yet? No, seriously. There’s nothing new I can add to this that hasn’t already been said. This is my one and only recommendation to non-anime fans.

It’s impossible to talk about without spoiling it. The premise is extremely interesting. It’s very suspenseful. It’s one of those shows where you just have to pop in another episode to see what happens next. The characters are great, especially the main one. It feels clever, and it’s satisfying to see characters trying to out think one another.

The reason I’m bringing this up is because Death Note is 7 years old. I have a theory that because there’s always new anime fans, they don’t have the same experience as older fans (they have shit taste). There’s probably a lot of them that haven’t seen this.

Just one warning though. DO NOT continue after episode 25. No matter how curious you are, do yourself a favor and pretend episodes 26 to 37 don’t exist. Unless you have OCD then you're not obligated to accept everything you're shown.

Examples:

  • - I pretend The Matrix sequels don't exist.
  • - I pretend the Mass Effect 3 ending doesn't exist. In fact, the fan theory is more interesting.
  • - I pretend the flashbacks and the last 15 minutes to The Maze Runner don't exist.
  • - I pretend the last 5 minutes of the Edge of Tomorrow doesn't exist.

While this is cherry picking, it only works for the beginnings, endings, and—most importantly—if the movie can still hold up after the mental editing.

uri:kitsu/reviews/content.@value:
**<u>Death Note - About a book</u>**

Randomly, a book drops down at a school and Light Yagami, a normal student, turns in to a serial murder with his new book, the Death Note. "L", a
high-rated detective is look for him. Light is unknown in public, so he gets the fantasy name "Kira". From now on, the only thing what will be read
about in the newspaper is, Kira vs. L. A close game between two near boys.

What does "near" mean? Watch it, and find it out.

Kind regards,

~ Marco S.

uri:kitsu/reviews/content.@value:
The show had a great main idea and was full of suspense and thrills. However, lots of times during the show it tended to lose it's momentum, using crazy plot twist that just didn't feel like they fit and made me feel like I was watching a completely different show. The ending left a lot to be desired. Sure it was a logical conclusion, but not a desirable one. It's hard not to say the show is good, because it has so many good aspects. Thrill, excitement, interesting characters, a great plot.... But the extreme plot twist tended to just ruin the whole experience, and the ending made it feel like it wasn't really worth all those hours, despite all the good things. For a show that has so many plot twist and always leaves you thinking you know everything, than being shocked to figure out you were completely wrong, the ending just seemed... too easy. It was a basic sad ending, nothing more to it. Defiantly not the kind of ending I'd expect from a show of this kind, so it was a big let down.

Considering how popular it is, and how thrilling it was, I can't really say I regret watching it, and I defiantly think it's worth it for the thrills and to be able to say you saw it. However, don't get your hopes up for the ending. It was a very dull way to conclude a thrilling series.

uri:kitsu/reviews/content.@value:
A quick review of Death Note with no direct spoilers (my thoughts on the first half and second half/ending, but nothing about the story itself).

First Part EP 1-25 the "meat" of the story was absolutely amazing and very well done. The story pacing was almost perfect and very little filler.

Second Part 26-37 the "crumbs", was lackluster and felt tacked on and expanded with filler of what could have been 6 episodes. Ending with what
arguably was a boring, unoriginal and disappointing conclusion.

If I were to grade them separately, the first half would undoubtedly get a 9/10, the second half a 6/10. I still would highly recommend watching the
series if the plot interests you as it's worth watching to conclusion just to have the story "finished".

The animation while going on 10 years now still holds up incredibly well today (despite the fact only 480p format exists, BR may be coming next month
possibly).

uri:kitsu/reviews/content.@value:
This show is very intriguing. At times it may seem that the story is slowing down, but BAM! it hits you with an unexpected twist. Having plot twists
can be a key element in a show like Death Note. It may help this anime gain points. However, having plot twists occur frequently can get old.

The main character in this anime, Light (or Kira) is so smart you can find yourself dumbfounded by how much intelligence was fused into his plans.
Even when his memory is erased (not much of a spoiler), he still has a massive amount of passion for doing what he does right.

The characters in this anime are so strong and are literally the whole point of Death Note. Without such strong opinions, Death Note would not exist.
Though at times you may think "They know the answer! Why are they denying themselves?". There is really no answer.

The sound and animation are nothing to write home about. There are no special features or goodies. It is merely average work.

uri:kitsu/reviews/content.@value:
I suppose when I look at my scoring this looks like a rather poorly rated anime by me, but the truth is it's great. It's just that many small things
take away from the score... and one big thing.

Lets dig a bit deeper...

Story: A guy finds a notebook and the directions claim it would kill anyone named.. he decides to give it a try mostly on a whim, and is shocked to
find it worked.

There is nothing wrong with the plot and most questions your already asking yourself will be answered. One of the strongest points of this anime is
the way the plot progresses and keeps you watching from one episode to the next. One of those shows I'm willing to wager will keep you watching from
one show to the next without waiting or wanting breaks.

Animation: Honestly the animation is rather weak. Overuse of dark colors as well as bland background and even characters. I've definitely seen worse
but that doesn't make this good. Their clothing has lots of detail - other than that I can't praise much.

Sound: The americanized opening is hard rock bordering on heavy metal. If you love that stuff, you'll like it but I didn't think it really fit. If
you don't like hard rock/metal I recommend the Japanese opening but neither one is particularly good. The voice acting is a mix of average and bad.
fortunately the major characters are watchable and there is really only one truly annoying character and she doesn't appear until later. The rest are
simply forgettable.

Final statements: My enjoyment level would have gotten a perfect 10 if only the second half of the show didn't exist, The characters would have
gotten a 9 if the second half of the show didn't exist, and the story would have gotten a perfect 10, Overall it would have gotten a 9 as well. That
is the difference the second half made to me. I recommend stopping there - You will know it when it happens.

uri:kitsu/users/about.@value: When it comes to reviewing anime I think of myself as brutally honest. I will point out flaws even in my favorite animes. If an anime is popular I feel someone needs to speak about it's flaws since there are enough people who are praising it already. Likewise if an anime is hated a lot I will point out good things about it. That doesn't mean it isn't still bad - it just means I like to show that almost everything has SOME good or bad.

uri:kitsu/reviews/content.@value:
Death Note, the greatest anime I have seen. Okay, it's not my favourite anime (although it's up there) and it probably won't be yours either, but
it is extremely well made.

Dialogue and voice-acting, art and symbolism, music and atmosphere - these are the things that Death Note does well. Both the manga and the anime were
made with careful consideration of these things and that shows. Death Note is notably lacking in the character development department but that isn't
what the story is about. Death Note is about Yagami Light and L's game of cat and mouse - it's about suspense and thrill.

Death Note felt like energy converging into a single point and then exploding when a result came about. That isn't describing the overall plot
either, there are multiple ventures from Yagami and L that make Death Note so good. The genius of the writing and of the two characters makes for a
very exciting game of cat and mouse. Death Note isn't without it's failures. Death Note suffers from 'crappy second arc syndrome', similar to
Sword Art Online. It could be said that to enjoy Death Note to the fullest, 'watch it only up to episode 26 (of its 37).' The comparison of the
amazing first half and average second half may be harsh, but it's true.

Death Note's theme is one about justice and what we would do if we had the power to change the world. This question provides the dark undertone to
the series which the music and art convey notably well. There are scenes in Death Note which make you sit back for a moment and think 'damn, this is
really well made.' I can't stress enough how well Death Note is crafted, the music and art come together so well and create great pieces of anime.

TL;DR - Death Note is a masterpiece, it features excellent quality however after episode 26 it doesn't live up to itself. A definite must watch, if
you haven't already seen it.

uri:kitsu/reviews/content.@value:
Easily one of the best anime's ever. The story is as original as anything I have ever seen or read. The lead characters are well developed and not
cookie cutter types from the anime genre. I found it increadably suspenseful. It was one of the few stories I couldn't wait to see what happened
next. The entire series kept me captivated and I never grew tired of if, unlike most anime where I get tired of it at some point. It also didn't take
several to a dozen episodes to take hold. From the first episode, I was captivated. 

I use to think this would be a good show or manga to introduce people who are new to anime or manga. But I've rethought that. I'm afraid if they saw
or read this first, they might be disappointed with anything they watched From then on. There are not many others that are in the same class as Death
Note.

uri:kitsu/reviews/content.@value:
**<u>Story: (9/10)</u>**

The story of Death Note is gripping, every episode has you on the edge of your seat wanting to work out what could happen next. However, there was a
part in the anime in which the story got a bit stale. The gimmick of the book died out and this did take away from the anime but the Story was solid
for the majority.

**<u>Animation: (8/10)</u>**

The animation was also solid for the most part. However, it does become dark and I did find myself having to adjust the brightness on many occasions.

**<u>Character: (8/10)</u>**

The characters are all really interesting my personal favourite (who tends to be fan favourite) is L and for you to know why I do recommend watching
the anime.

**<u>Sound: (9/10)</u>**

The soundtrack for this anime was incredible all the tracks were immense I loved every single one of them. It really builds the atmosphere for the
entire anime.

**<u>Enjoyment: (9/10)</u>**

I really enjoyed the anime, in fact it was my first ever anime (next to hunter x hunter) and its story and characters really have made me watch more
psychological anime. The anime has a lot of hype and so it should because it is a solid anime for any one who wants to come into the genre.

uri:kitsu/reviews/content.@value:
This is a Review out of 100. 35/100 for Story, 35/100 for Characters, 15/100 for Sound, 15/100 for Animation.Story - 28/35 - The story was very
original, especially for a shounen series. Instead of physical fights, this show opted for mental fights, or mind games. You never really knew what
would happen next, and while the show followed a cat vs mouse flow, you never knew who was gonna be the cat and who was gonna be the mouse. The show
also brought up the question of what you would do if you were in a similar position of power, and shows how easily power can corrupt people. Sadly, I
was not a big fan of the Near and Mello arc, as I think the writing in the series took a nose dive. Characters also started getting stupid for plot
convenience, especially Light. Personally, I'd have a lot more nice things to say about the show if it would have ended around episode 25/26.
Characters - 29/35 - I really like Light Yagami as a character. You almost want to agree with what he was doing. L is equally as appealing. Really, a
lot of the characters are good, but only those two really stand out. There are also quite a few annoying characters, like Misa and Matsuda.I already
expressed my dislike of the near and Mello arc, and they are no small reason as to why. Also, for a group of people trying to track down someone so
important, they seem pretty lax most of the time. I felt they were a little too unprofessional is all. Overall, an above average cast of characters.
Sound - 14/15 - The Music was really good, although it felt a bit out of place a times. We can all agree that the chorus was not needed when Light was
eating that potato chip. The opening and ending songs were especially good.Most people would agree that the English Dub of the show is pretty good,
probably rivaling the Japanese. I'd recommend you watch it in English unless you really hate Light or L's voice or something. Animation - 13/15 -
The animation was very solid. I also really like how the director chose to use Red to represent Light and Blue to represent L. It was a nice effect.
Overall - 84/100 - I like Death Note a lot. It was one of the series that really changed my outlook on anime and helped mold the kind of shows I like
today. But I can't ignore it's shortcomings, specifically in the story department. I'd consider this to be a potential classic if it weren't for
that last arc.

uri:kitsu/reviews/content.@value: So, finally I get around to Death Note. Is it freaking good? You bet. Is it as freaking good as most people claim it to be? Yes and no. Death Note is a psychological thriller that kept me on my feet up until about episode 13. Then it kind of slowed down, but then around episode 22 it gets better, up until 25. For the five of you out there that haven't seen Death Note I won't spoil, but ep 25 is a really high peak...and then it goes down again. Don't get me wrong. Most people really dislike the last part of this anime, after ep 25 until 37, but I enjoyed it almost as much as before. I say *almost*, for several reasons, mostly because in those eps the screen writers seemed tired of putting intricate mental twists on everything and made the characters think less smartly and arrive the right conclusion "because they said so".It was not as polished as the first half. I also would like to talk about the character of Light Yagami. For as much as he was the main character and all, I never really liked him. I was glad when L got the better of him at times. He's just such a asshole with a God complex,even though I admired him for his intelligence, I could never bring myself to root for him, like I did, for example, for Lelouch from Code Geass, a character that is very similar to Light in many ways. But Lelouch seemed to me like the more rounded character. He had terrible faults, but he remained likable because he was human. Light was not human. He was willing to kill anyone to accomplish his goals, and never once did he show struggle before having to murder.He felt like a two dimensional evil character, with no complexity in him. I suppose not liking the protagonist could have harmed my enjoyment of this show, but I really liked it, overall. It's a great anime,totally worth its hype.

I say almost, for several reasons, mostly because in those eps the screen writers seemed tired of putting intricate mental twists on everything and made the characters think less smartly and arrive the right conclusion "because they said so".It was not as polished as the first half.

I also would like to talk about the character of Light Yagami. For as much as he was the main character and all, I never really liked him. I was glad when L got the better of him at times. He's just such a asshole with a God complex,even though I admired him for his intelligence, I could never bring myself to root for him, like I did, for example, for Lelouch from Code Geass, a character that is very similar to Light in many ways. But Lelouch seemed to me like the more rounded character. He had terrible faults, but he remained likable because he was human. Light was not human. He was willing to kill anyone to accomplish his goals, and never once did he show struggle before having to murder.He felt like a two dimensional evil character, with no complexity in him.

I suppose not liking the protagonist could have harmed my enjoyment of this show, but I really liked it, overall. It's a great anime,totally worth its hype.

I love a smart anime, and death note is one of the greatest. It's greatness is famous throughout the anime community by so much it occasionally leaks
out to the general public. It's a psychological thriller that is a rare example of what anime could really be. It's story lacks any holes, it's
characters are believable and the animation fits the show perfect. Not only that but the music is favored among anime watchers as the greatest
thinking music ever. Many complain about it's second half but i was fine with it, however it was a change of pace. It takes itself a little too
seriously at some points but this only adds to the atmosphere to the show. I'm making a video review on this soon.

The Death Note anime...wish me luck!:-D(Sorry about the poor grammar/spelling)STORY (6)Yeah, I gave the Death Note story a 6...got a problem with
that??:'(. Let me explain. The reason that I gave the plot a lower rating than the norm is because the second half of the series had a serious dip in
the enjoyment factor. Am I alone in assuming that Near is a very unlikeable character?? I loved the first half of the season! It was a lot fun
watching the cat and mouse mind games between L and Kira. The manipulative mind games between Kira and his pursuers is the driving force behind the
whole series. This means that the success or failure of this series depends upon how enjoyable these games can be, so when the mind games stop being
entertaining...failure...One of the negative points of this anime is that (at times) it tries to be too serious and epic and it just comes out as
silly and cheesy. Epic is good, but all good things in moderation.ART (7)I'm certainly no expert when it comes to judging animation, so I'm gonna
keep this nice and short. I thought it was pretty good.(hah you thought I was gonna say something meaningful:-D)...but in all seriousness, I don't
really have any complaint with the animation. I liked how the anime characters still looked like the manga characters(you know how sometimes you read
a manga then you go to see the anime(or vice versa)and you're like "Wait...WHAT?? Who is this character!?!?"...yeah...).SOUND (7)Overall, I thought
that the music was pretty good. The opening is really catchy and fits the series. The ending is good, but unmemorable. The music throughout the
episodes usually help to make a scene even more epic...EXCEPT when the series starts trying too hard and every Kira/L/Near/Mellow scene just HAS to be
epic...\*sigh\*...ENJOYMENT (8)For all my b\*\*ching bout the second half of the series, I still gave Death Note a fairly high enjoyment rating. I
thought that no matter how much I didn't enjoy the last half, I still enjoyed the first half enough for it to earn an 8. I mean, who doesn't love an
anti-hero with a god complex:-D.OVERALL (7)Overall, I give this anime a 7! It would have been higher if the second half had been better, and if the
anime didn't feel like it was epically trolling me...As much as I talked bout the negative points of this anime, I still enjoyed Death Note. The
suspenseful mind games and interesting characters helped make up for much of this anime's flaws:-).

uri:kitsu/reviews/content.@value:
Psychological thrillers are easy to write, but not as easy to like. A lot of what makes psychological thrillers work is making the characters act in a
very believable and human fashion, which we don't normally see because the writers make the themes normally control the story and characters in
psychological thrillers. This tends to ruin immersion a lot, especially when the purpose of such a story is to discuss the humanity behind their
actions or lack thereof.

The trick behind psychological thrillers is to also avoid making the story as dark as possible simply for the purpose of being, well, as dark as
possible. It's very easy for them to slide into being too edgy for their own good, which not only ruins immersion by the viewers but also ends up
contradicting the themes of the show.

Death Note is a case where this is avoided...and played straight.

The storyline is undeniably tightly written and many of the tricks and red herrings are carefully played out over the course of the show, especially
in the first two thirds. This works thanks to the fascinating perspectives on justice, morality and even religion present over the course of the show,
which is brilliantly handled when focusing on the society at large and many of the various side characters.

The show doesn't work as well, however, when focusing these themes on the main characters. It feels like the show dumbed down a lot of character
depth simply to make the pacing as addictive and fast as possible, which works if you look at what this show does on a basic level (as far as
storytelling is concerned, it definitely knows how to hook the viewer) but it's hard not to feel like layers of depth were cut out simply to make the
show as, well, thrilling as possible.

Speaking of the main characters, it's impossible to bring up the main characters without focusing on the fantastic rivalry between Light and L, which
is very well explored and grows fantastically throughout the show. 

This does bring us to another important point that ends up being what prevents this show from being a masterpiece; the moral ambiguity that works so
damn well on everything else fails when focusing on Light and L, and that is because the show avoids making you root for Light by making him as much
of a megalomaniac as possible. Light is simply a tool to advance the themes, and while this isn't particularly bizarre for a psychological thriller
it fails in a show so rooted in morality such as this one.

Light is a prime example of a great idea for a character gone terribly wrong, and while he is certainly a great deal of entertainment to watch over
the course of the show, there is no conflict he holds within himself despite that being, well, the nature of the show. This leads to a lot of
inconsistent characterization, especially in the final third of the show where the show just wants him to be painted as the most evil person possible.
Sure, watching him slowly but surely slide into madness was a lot of fun but I couldn't help but feel that it could have been handled a lot better.

The artwork is very distinct and pleasant to look at, with character designs being very distinct and the backgrounds looking great. The scenery is
absolutely gorgeous over the course of the show, and the visuals look even smoother in the more tense moment of the series. Animation quality is solid
and consistent and does a fantastic job bringing out the tension over the course of the show (despite the fact that you, the viewer, know all the
information before the characters do). This show is filled with adrenaline and it knows it, and it works very well.

The soundtrack is pretty rad as well, with some absolutely chilling choirs being played over the course of the show. The sound effects never feel out
of place, and constantly and consistently fit the mood. The voice acting in both Japanese and English is top notch and it's hard to recommend one
over the other, though I personally think the dub sounds better (simply because L sounds more like an introvert and Light doesn't sound as much like
an adult).

Overall, Death Note is a highly enjoyable anime that unfortunately suffers from being very inconsistent in its presentation, doesn't succeed at being
morally ambiguous when it matters most as much as it should have and has a considerably weaker final third than the first two thirds of the show.

It is nonetheless a show I can recommend as among the best entries in the mystery genre as far as anime is concerned, and if not for anything else it
certainly leaves a lot of food for thought.   
I recommend it, but please be aware that contrary to what you may hear, it's not everyone's cup of tea (I swear I'm not making a reference to
anything in the show) and a lot of the themes may offend some people, especially as far as religion in particular is concerned.

Those who can look past all that will find a flawed but adrenaline pumping show rich in themes and symbolism and mixed in its execution.

(Adapted from my MAL review)

Have you ever thought about the way the world is now? Have you seen it in a positive light or a negative light? Have you ever thought about how you
can change the world you're living in, for what you think is the better? Then one day, you find yourself with an unlikely weapon which you use to
change the world.

Welcome to one of the most critically-acclaimed anime in the world, "Death Note".

The story begins with Light Yagami, a 17-year-old high school student who is basically bored with his entire life. One day, he notices a mysterious,
black notebook literally fall from the sky. Of course, since Light is human, this particular notebook piques his curiosity. This particular notebook
is labeled "Death Note", and according to what is said inside of the Death Note, anyone whose name is written in it will die. Light initially thinks
that it's fake, but he discovers it's real after testing it out. Now, aided by the Shinigami Ryuk (who was the one who dropped the Death Note into
the human realm in the first place), Light sets out to create a "better" world by using his Death Note to "punish" criminals. Meanwhile, as all of
these deaths are happening, the police, aided by a man known only as L, try to catch the man behind the deaths, who are known to them as "Kira".

I don't know if I even need to explain all this, though. If you haven't at least heard of Death Note, I don't know if I can say that you're a true
anime fan. (No offense intended.) It was through all this hype that I was finally tempted to watch Death Note myself. Now, after watching all 37
episodes, I know what all of the hype is about.

Let me start by talking about the story. It's clear that the story is the strongest point of Death Note. It's a suspenseful story with lots of
twists and turns. Although some parts of the story had been spoiled to me even before I started watching it (for example, the way it ends), that did
not stop me from not being able to really guess what I didn't already know. Thus, I can't say I hate the story at all, even if some parts of it were
ruined for me.

Now, the characters. There was quite a number of interesting characters in this series, but were ALL of them likable? Of course not. In fact, some of
Light's actions left me really hating him. Yeah, I just said I don't like Light, who is the protagonist whom the viewers are supposed to be
following all of the way. Think about it, though; while it's great that he punishes criminals, he also makes the loved ones of those criminals sad.
What's worse, he hardly feels any remorse toward them. Then, you've got L, who is basically Light's opponent. While I didn't know exactly what to
think of him at first, I eventually grew to like him. What happens to him in the anime, which I refuse to spoil for anyone who hasn't seen it, really
was a shame.

The animation was rather well done; it really gives off the intense atmosphere there is most times. All of the opening and ending themes were pretty
awesome, too, especially the first opening. It matched the anime very well for the time that it was the opening theme. I should probably mention that
I was watching the English dub for Death Note. The voice actors did an excellent job, especially (believe it or not) Brad Swaile as Light.

For the amount of time that I spent watching Death Note, I can say that I greatly enjoyed it. It's a suspenseful police drama that is not all that
predictable unless you were giving spoilers for it. I guess the series getting spoiled for me was what killed some of my enjoyment. Even so, the hype
for Death Note is well worth it; I'd say you give it a try. Oh, and while you watch it, try taking a potato chip and eating it. (You'll catch the
reference soon enough.)

\[Short and Spoiler-Free Review\]

Death Note is one of the best and most suspenseful series I've ever seen, anime or otherwise... but only through the 7th episode.

Death Note suffers from complete Episode 7 Syndrome, but its initial momentum is so powerful that it can easily carry the viewer's interest another
19 episodes.  Unfortunately, the payoff is disproportionately low, and the series ends with a bland and unsatisfying conclusion.  While it does end up
completing the individual stories of all its important characters from start to finish, the series never fulfills the hype it generates in its first
seven incredible episodes.

Now don't get me wrong, the original concept is way cool, and the themes the show initially explores with it are fascinating.  Unfortunately, like
most anime that suffer from E7S, the author had a great idea but didn't know where to go after kicking things off.

The first seven episodes is the story of "an average high school boy", Light Yagami, finding the Death Note, discovering what it does, and
discovering he likes it.  But as he begins to use it in an attempt to better the world, he is unaware of how quickly such a power could potentially
corrupt his morality.  

Early on Light remains confident he can maintain his much-needed secrecy by wielding the Death Note's under the pseudonym Kira.  However, an
extremely (and unreasonably) intelligent investigator, named L, quickly backs Light into a corner and within days of beginning of his investigation is
within a hair's breadth of discovering Light's true identity.

Light's inward desperation and dread on being discovered is so awesome to experience, and the constant suspense of whether he will be discovered is
just thrilling.  The episodes are start to finish flawless and engaging, and it's hard to not just binge-watch once the first two episodes are over.
 

While there is an extreme sense of dread and suspense in Death Note's first seven episodes, at the 8th episode the story loses most of its intensity.
 It goes big and expands, introducing new characters and Death Note tricks and a host of other elements, when really, it just doesn't need to.  And,
the story artificially slows down, which I feel was an overt attempt by the author to keep things going for an artificially long period of time.

Ultimately, Death Note is an awesome concept, and is a story which would have best been told in a single 13-episode season.  The first seven episodes
are some of the best suspense I've ever seen, and should not be missed.  But after that... there are better ways to kill time.

[Short and Spoiler-Free Review]

Death Note is one of the best and most suspenseful series I've ever seen, anime or otherwise... but only through the 7th episode.

Death Note suffers from complete Episode 7 Syndrome, but its initial momentum is so powerful that it can easily carry the viewer's interest another 19 episodes.  Unfortunately, the payoff is disproportionately low, and the series ends with a bland and unsatisfying conclusion.  While it does end up completing the individual stories of all its important characters from start to finish, the series never fulfills the hype it generates in its first seven incredible episodes.

Now don't get me wrong, the original concept is way cool, and the themes the show initially explores with it are fascinating.  Unfortunately, like most anime that suffer from E7S, the author had a great idea but didn't know where to go after kicking things off.

The first seven episodes is the story of "an average high school boy", Light Yagami, finding the Death Note, discovering what it does, and discovering he likes it.  But as he begins to use it in an attempt to better the world, he is unaware of how quickly such a power could potentially corrupt his morality.  

Early on Light remains confident he can maintain his much-needed secrecy by wielding the Death Note's under the pseudonym Kira.  However, an extremely (and unreasonably) intelligent investigator, named L, quickly backs Light into a corner and within days of beginning of his investigation is within a hair's breadth of discovering Light's true identity.

Light's inward desperation and dread on being discovered is so awesome to experience, and the constant suspense of whether he will be discovered is just thrilling.  The episodes are start to finish flawless and engaging, and it's hard to not just binge-watch once the first two episodes are over.  

While there is an extreme sense of dread and suspense in Death Note's first seven episodes, at the 8th episode the story loses most of its intensity.  It goes big and expands, introducing new characters and Death Note tricks and a host of other elements, when really, it just doesn't need to.  And, the story artificially slows down, which I feel was an overt attempt by the author to keep things going for an artificially long period of time.

Ultimately, Death Note is an awesome concept, and is a story which would have best been told in a single 13-episode season.  The first seven episodes are some of the best suspense I've ever seen, and should not be missed.  But after that... there are better ways to kill time.

I gave the story an 8 and everything else a solid 9's across the board. The story would have gotten a 9 if I rated it on or before about episode 20,
and an easy 10 if it was within the first 5-10 episodes or so. Without giving too much away, it's hard to explain why -- but I just felt that certain
plot arcs were drawn out longer than they needed to be, certain characters didn't need to be introduced to the story at all, and certain others
should have stuck around until the end. All in all, I still enjoyed the anime as a whole, despite absolutely dispising the opening credit song for the
second half of the series.Everything except Art could have been a 10 though (I save 10s for art that makes me actually jump out of my seat and go
"OMG the art in this is AMAZING!!"), so in the end, yes, Death Note is a great anime definitely worth watching, but not enough to get 10's across
the board... but it was.. so.. close.

uri:kitsu/reviews/content.@value:
In America, people die by obesity, in Africa, people die by starvation, in Japan, people die by notebooks...wait what? If you watch anime, then
you've probably already watched Death Note, I mean what kind of person hasn't watched Death Note yet? Death Note is a series that has been loved and
praised ever since it came out and even today it's still one of the most popular anime there is. It's not the perfect anime, but definitely one of
the most memorable. The first half is something amazing that only god (Kira) would have given us and it's something you can't forget even if you
tried. The second half takes a step back, it's definitely not as good as the first half, but is still good nevertheless.

Story: 9/10   
The story of Death Note is about our overachieving protagonist, Light Yagami, AKA, Kira. He was just walking home after school one day when all of a
sudden, a random notebook falls from the sky called the Death Note, whoever's name is written in the Death Note, will die. Light picks it up and
writes someone's name because he doesn't believe it. And that's when Light is in shock because PEOPLE DIE IF THEY ARE KILLED! Isn't that right
Shiro? The story is amazing, and one of the best story lines I've ever seen. It's full of mind games, strategy, and suspense. You could say it's
perfect, but the second half stops it from being so. The second half introduced two characters to the story, Near and Mello, although they're both
important to the story, they're both very dull and only weigh the story down by making me lose interest. The mind games and strategy were still great
in the second half, but Near and Mello stop the story from being as interesting as the first half. The only thing I thought that was better in the
second half than the first was the ending. And in my opinion, it was the best way to end this series. I mean what other anime has you killing people
with a notebook.

Art/Animation: 10/10  
The Art style is definitely one of my favourite art style in anime and fits Death Note really well, with a mix of realism and anime. The animation is
also fantastic. It builds the suspense and keeps you on the edge of your seat because everything in Death Note is exaggerated. For example, imagine
Light Yagami writing a name in the Death Note, pretty simple right? Now imagine him writing a name in the Death Note with awesome animation, shaky
camera shots, and epic choir music in the background. And Death Note does this all the time with different scenes such as car chases, mind games,
writing in a notebook, or even eating a potato chip. If you don't understand, you have to watch Death Note to actually know.

Sound: 10/10  
The soundtrack was absolutely fantastic, hands down one of the best soundtracks I've ever had the pleasure of listening to. All opening and ending
themes were great to listen to and fit the series well. I don't have much to say about the soundtrack because I've already summed it all up into the
first sentence. The soundtrack will give you goosebumps, send chill right through your spine and make you orgasm right through your ears.

Characters: 7/10  
The Characters was the worst part about the show, but it's not bad either. There were lots of great characters that received plenty of character
development, such as Matsuda, and definitely Light and L and most, if not all the characters served a purpose to the story. It's just that some
characters were dull and made me lose interest in the story such a Mello and Near, both of them were boring characters and I did not like them at all.
Another character I didn't really like was Misa, she was an important character, but she was kind of annoying to me, she reminded me of "Overly
obsessed girlfriend" and Juvia from Fairy Tail, I just didn't really like her, but that's just my opinion. Everyone else in the cast were great.

Enjoyment: 9/10   
Death Note was a blast to watch. It gave my goosebumps, blew my mind, and made me want to watch more every episode. The music was more than enough to
pump me up, and the animation kept me on the edge of my seat. I just wished there were more anime as original as Death Note was.

Overall, Death Note is an awesome anime to watch, especially if you like mature, psychological, mystery anime. If you haven't watch this anime, GO
WATCH IT NOW, or else our god, Kira will write your name down in the Death Note, I'm kidding. In the end, we all know who our god really is, and
that's none other than Haruhi Suzumyia! Just kidding. I'm ohhenry2, and I give Death Note, an amazing 9/10

uri:kitsu/reviews/content.@value:
Note: Not professional just going to discuss the second half of Death Note.

So, no one has problems with the first half of Death Note and if it was just that this anime would probably be in the top 3 Highest ranking animes but everyone seems to hate the second half for legitimate reasons but most don't seem to understand the point of the second half.
-First of all the second half was not meant to be like the first half.
-Yes Near and Mello were shitty and could never compare to L but they were just there to help in moving the point of the Second half forward.
-The second half was there to showcase the fall of Kira after he had beaten L, he became cocky and the madness overtook him as well that's the reason he lost to Near and dies. Near was never smart as L but since Light was cocky he made stupid mistakes.
-The main point of the anime was for you to question morality (Is it right to kill a criminal). 
-So many people compare Code Geass to Death Note for minor reasons but that is not true in my opinion Monster is the true successor to Death Note.
-This anime is recommended for more intelligent people (In term of Mentally such as people who tend to be philosophical).
-The ending (even though I disliked it) was very fitting and there could be no better ending for what this anime was trying to showcase. In the end Light regrets killing L and wishes he could have stayed a normal student.

So I still will give Death Note a 10/10 review and it is and will always be my first and (tied for) favorite (with Monster) anime.

uri:kitsu/reviews/content.@value: You know everyone has their own gateway to anime. Mine is Death Note. What Death Note taught me is that the word "Epic" can form not only through fighting and cool action but also through narration, storyline and suspension. Story The story of Death Note can be explained quite easily, it's about our main character, Light Yagami, one day suddenly picked up a notebook entitled "Death Note". As you would expect, any name written down on the note will die. Then, Light decided to use this miracle book to bring justice upon the world and cleanse all of evil by writing down as much bad guy as possible. That was the background apparently. **+The positive:** 1. It is never boring at least for the first 12 episodes 2. Events that are happening are shown in great detail which allows the viewer to fully comprehend the story 3. Great suspension and build up to keep the viewer from getting bored 4. Not your typical good vs evil stuff, but rather it's about the viewer's judgement on who's evil and who's righteous 5. Well-paced and directed, this show made everything as epic as humanly possible, even from playing tennis to eating potatoes chip! **- The negative:** 1. As the show drag on, it kept getting worse. The show is really interesting up until episode 12, where it suddenly had a change of arc. At first it still bearable up until episode 25, and then everything onward is just a complete mess 2. Become more forceful as it goes on, should just have ended on episode 25 3. Losses it's touch and that epic feels, as if the show itself doesn't want to go on anymore 4. The ending Animation Death Note was made by the famous studio Mad House, they did a really good job in creating the animation. Although the animation can be a little stiff sometimes but overall, it's a pleasant experience to watch it. The cinematography is where it really shine here, as the director, Tetsuro Araki, done a great job making the atmosphere of the show really epic. **+The positive:** 1. Excellent directing 2. Excellent cinematography 3. Good artwork **-The negative:**1. Sometimes stiff character movement 2. Background can be more detail Sound Death Note has a really amazing soundtrack. The main purpose of soundtrack is to support the scene and deliver the feeling and atmosphere to the audience and Death Note has done this really well. The OP and ED are both very heavy metal and suit the show just fine. The OST matches to the scenes extremely well and are some of the best original soundtrack out there. Special note to "L Theme" as it is just amazing. **+The positive**\: 1. Matches the scene perfectly 2. Very original 3. L theme **-The negative:**1. Because of the show's long duration, the OST can be easily get bored of Character There are 2 characters that can be say as the icon of Death Note Light Yagami and L **Light Yagami** is an honoured high school student who always ace his grade. He believes himself to be the god of the new world as he can kill anyone just by writing down their name on the death note. He is dedicated in changing the world to a crime free world. The problem is, as the show goes on, he seems to lost sight of his goal and he slowing turning more pathetic. Epic Light (first half of the show) WTF is this? (second half of the show) I myself is a Light supporter because e uses his high level of intelligence to trick and manipulate people around him to get what he want. Therefore, he is one of my favourite character of all time, only if he didn't turn out the way he is at the end sigh~~~**** **L** is a world renowned super detective, he is known to be able to solve impossible cases but only the one he interested in. Of course he is dedicated to stop Light Yagami killing spree as he believe what Light did was no justice but simply a massacre. He is shown with a level of intelligence on par or even higher than Light Yagami's. The only bad thing about the character of this show is probably how Light became the way he is in the end. I find no problem at all with other characters. I try not to spoil anything so I won't mention other characters Enjoyment For the first 12, it is one of my most enjoyable anime. This show always manage to build up high tension and execute it in an epic manners. Up until episode 25 and above, then it just turn to crap. Seriously, episode 1-12 was crazy, episode 13-25 was quite amazing, episode 25-end was total rubbish *especially the ending*! I did not enjoy the ending at all. Overall Overall, Death Note is an amazing anime but slowly turn to something it was not meant to be. It's an great example of how an anime can start marvellously and end horribly. Despite the bad second half and crap ending, the show first half was so amazing that I can't just ignore it. Therefore, I still recommend this to anyone and anyone who hasn't seen Death Note, you should give this a try, who knows maybe you'll enjoy it more than I do. Death Note - 8.7 ***"I am the God of the new world"*** Light Yagami

uri:kitsu/reviews/contentFormatted.@value:
You know everyone has their own gateway to anime. Mine is Death Note. What Death Note taught me is that the word "Epic" can form not only through fighting and cool action but also through narration, storyline and suspension.

Story

The story of Death Note can be explained quite easily, it's about our main character, Light Yagami, one day suddenly picked up a notebook entitled "Death Note". As you would expect, any name written down on the note will die. Then, Light decided to use this miracle book to bring justice upon the world and cleanse all of evil by writing down as much bad guy as possible. That was the background apparently.

+The positive:

  1. It is never boring at least for the first 12 episodes
  2. Events that are happening are shown in great detail which allows the viewer to fully comprehend the story
  3. Great suspension and build up to keep the viewer from getting bored
  4. Not your typical good vs evil stuff, but rather it's about the viewer's judgement on who's evil and who's righteous
  5. Well-paced and directed, this show made everything as epic as humanly possible, even from playing tennis to eating potatoes chip!

- The negative:

  1. As the show drag on, it kept getting worse. The show is really interesting up until episode 12, where it suddenly had a change of arc. At first it still bearable up until episode 25, and then everything onward is just a complete mess
  2. Become more forceful as it goes on, should just have ended on episode 25
  3. Losses it's touch and that epic feels, as if the show itself doesn't want to go on anymore
  4. The ending
Animation

Death Note was made by the famous studio Mad House, they did a really good job in creating the animation. Although the animation can be a little stiff sometimes but overall, it's a pleasant experience to watch it. The cinematography is where it really shine here, as the director, Tetsuro Araki, done a great job making the atmosphere of the show really epic.

+The positive:

  1. Excellent directing
  2. Excellent cinematography
  3. Good artwork
-The negative:
  1. Sometimes stiff character movement
  2. Background can be more detail
Sound

Death Note has a really amazing soundtrack. The main purpose of soundtrack is to support the scene and deliver the feeling and atmosphere to the audience and Death Note has done this really well. The OP and ED are both very heavy metal and suit the show just fine. The OST matches to the scenes extremely well and are some of the best original soundtrack out there. Special note to "L Theme" as it is just amazing.

+The positive:

  1. Matches the scene perfectly
  2. Very original
  3. L theme
-The negative:
  1. Because of the show's long duration, the OST can be easily get bored of
Character

There are 2 characters that can be say as the icon of Death Note

Light Yagami and L

Light Yagami is an honoured high school student who always ace his grade. He believes himself to be the god of the new world as he can kill anyone just by writing down their name on the death note. He is dedicated in changing the world to a crime free world. The problem is, as the show goes on, he seems to lost sight of his goal and he slowing turning more pathetic.

Epic Light (first half of the show)

WTF is this? (second half of the show)

I myself is a Light supporter because e uses his high level of intelligence to trick and manipulate people around him to get what he want. Therefore, he is one of my favourite character of all time, only if he didn't turn out the way he is at the end sigh~~~

L is a world renowned super detective, he is known to be able to solve impossible cases but only the one he interested in. Of course he is dedicated to stop Light Yagami killing spree as he believe what Light did was no justice but simply a massacre. He is shown with a level of intelligence on par or even higher than Light Yagami's.

The only bad thing about the character of this show is probably how Light became the way he is in the end. I find no problem at all with other characters.

I try not to spoil anything so I won't mention other characters

Enjoyment

For the first 12, it is one of my most enjoyable anime. This show always manage to build up high tension and execute it in an epic manners. Up until episode 25 and above, then it just turn to crap. Seriously, episode 1-12 was crazy, episode 13-25 was quite amazing, episode 25-end was total rubbish especially the ending! I did not enjoy the ending at all.

Overall

Overall, Death Note is an amazing anime but slowly turn to something it was not meant to be. It's an great example of how an anime can start marvellously and end horribly. Despite the bad second half and crap ending, the show first half was so amazing that I can't just ignore it. Therefore, I still recommend this to anyone and anyone who hasn't seen Death Note, you should give this a try, who knows maybe you'll enjoy it more than I do.

Death Note - 8.7

"I am the God of the new world"

Light Yagami
